conversion_factors_4.title: Conversion Factors 4

conversion_factors_4.objective: Convert a quantity to a different unit using three, four or more conversion factors; in particular convert mph to m/s with four conversion factors; properly write conversion factors to show how dimensional analysis is used

dimensional_analysis_2.title: Dimensional Analysis 2

conversion_factors_5.title: Conversion Factors 5

dimensions_and_units.title: Dimensions and Units
dimensions_and_units.objective: Define the terms quantity, dimensions, unit, and SI unit; for crucial physics quantities give the quantity, dimension, SI unit, and other units.

mathematical_foundations_of_dimensional_.title: Mathematical Foundations of Dimensional Analysis
mathematical_foundations_of_dimensional_.objective: State and describe the mathematical principles behind dimensional analysis.
notes: Units are written inside a formula; quantities are actually a number multiplied by a unit
Units are treated similarly to numbers or variables, they can be added, multiplied, divided, etc.
The unit of your answer is based on the unit your provide
All physics are based on a few basic units: meters, kilograms, seconds, and coulombs
All conversion factors are equal to 1, and can be multiplied to manipulate units as you want.

conversion_factors_6.title: Conversion Factors 6
conversion_factors_6.subtitle: Using Conversion Factors with Formulas
conversion_factors_6.objective: Use conversion factors together with formulas to solve novel and indirect problems.

derive_and_categorize_units.objective: Using physics formulas, derive all relevant physics quantities; categorize these quantities by their dimensions.

planck_units.title: Planck units
planck_units.objective: Use dimensional analysis to derive a set of units in which all physical constants are equal to one; Derive conversion factors between SI units and these units; Explain the significance of these units.

google_interview_questions_2.title: Google Interview Questions 2
google_interview_questions_2.objective: Invent interesting random, outside the box questions, and then answer them with dimensional analysis.

numeric_proportionality_1.title: Numeric Proportionality 1
numeric_proportionality_1.objective: Given a direct or inverse proportion between two variables, solve numerical problems on how one variable changes as the other does.

graphical_proportionality_1.title: Graphical Proportionality 1

graphical_proportionality_2.title: Graphical Proportionality 2
graphical_proportionality_2.objective: Recognize and draw graphs showing square, square root, inverse square, or inverse square root proportion between two variables.

equation_proportionality.objective: Given an equation, state the relationship between variables when other variables are constant (or satisfy other conditions; write effectively about proportions
examples: voltage and current are directly proportional when resistance is constant
displacement is proportional to the square of time when acceleration is constant and initial velocity is zero

variable_transformations_2.title: Variable Transformations 2
variable_transformations_2.objective: Algebraically modify a relationship a graph with a non-direct proportionality to a graph showing a direct proportionality in 3-4 algebraic steps; interpret the slope of the line of this graph.
examples: necessary to use a pendulum to measure free-fall acceleration

qualitative_vs_quantitative.title: Qualitative vs. Quantitative Reasoning
qualitative_vs_quantitative.objective: Define and give examples of qualitative and quantitative reasoning.
qualitative_vs_quantitative.content: A quantitative study is based on numerical measurements; a qualitative study is based on categories, patterns, or non-numerical observations

identify_variables_1.title: Identify Variables 1
identify_variables_1.objective: Given a description of an experiment, identify the independent, dependent, and controlled variable of the experiment.
identify_variables_1.content: In an experiment, an independent variable is systematically changed; a dependent variable is systematically measured; and a controlled variable is kept constant.

what_is_theory.title: What is a theory?
what_is_theory.objective: Define the term 'theory'; discuss how theories are shown to be consistent and inconsistent with data; differentiate between theoretical physics and experimental physics; define the terms theory and law
what_is_theory.content: A theory is a simple explanation of how the universe works; theories are used to derive predicted observations; by making real observations, theories are shown to be consistent or inconsistent with data; a law is a theory that has been consistently validated; theoretical physicists develop new theories while experimental physicists test those theories.

identify_variables_2.title: Identify Variables 2
identify_variables_2.objective: Given a description of an experiment, identify the independent, dependent, and controlled variables of the experiment; identify more than one controlled variable; define the term 'experiment' in terms of independent, dependent, and controlled variables; identify whether each variable is qualitative or quantitative.
identify_variables_2.content: In an experiment, an independent variable is systematically changed; a dependent variable is systematically measured; and a controlled variable is kept constant.
identify_variables_2.notes: More challenging examples than identify variables 1

good_theories.title: Good Theories
good_theories.objective: Define elements of a good theory: universality, parsimony, and clear limitations
good_theories.content: A universal theory applies to the entire universe; a parsimonious theory uses only a small number of simple rules; a theory with clear limitations has clearly defined conditions under which a different theory is used.

inductive_vs_deductive.title: Inductive and Deductive Reasoning
inductive_vs_deductive.objective: Define and give examples of inductive and deductive reasoning
inductive_vs_deductive.content: In a deductive study, a specific theory is used to make a prediction and then data is evaluated as either consistent or inconsistent with the theory; in an inductive study many different possibilities are tested to look for patterns and potential new theories.

identify_variables_3.title: Identify Variables 3
identify_variables_3.subtitle: The Pendulum Lab
identify_variables_3.objective: Use the concept of dependent, independent, and controlled variables to describe a procedure that includes more than one experiment.

design_experiment_1.title: Design Experiment 1
design_experiment_1.objective: Design an experiment that requires one procedure using the terms independent variable, dependent variable, and controlled variable

limits_of_theories.title: Limitations of Theories
limits_of_theories.objective: Give examples of how theories work within particular ranges; in particular, define the ranges of Newton's Laws.

qualitative_vs_quantitative_difference.title: Qualitatively Different vs. Qualitatively Different
qualitative_vs_quantitative_difference.objective: Give examples of situations in which items (or people) are either quantitatively or qualitative different.
qualitative_vs_quantitative_difference.notes: Could have some connection to psychology, or to sports, eg: was michael jordan quantitatively or qualitative different.

design_experiment_2.title: Design Experiment 2
design_experiment_2.objective: Design a complex investigation involving more than one experiment using the terms independent variable, dependent variable, and controlled variable.

peer_review_1.title: Peer Review 1
peer_review_1.objective: Complete a mock 'peer review' of a famous historical or hypothetical experiment.
peer_review_1.content: Peer Review is a process by which papers are accepted or denied from scientific journals; a peer review team evaluates a study for mathematical and scientific rigor.

peer_review_2.title: Peer Review 2
peer_review_2.objective: Complete a mock 'peer review' of a famous historical or hypothetical experiment.
peer_review_2.content: Peer Review is a process by which papers are accepted or denied from scientific journals; a peer review team evaluates a study for mathematical and scientific rigor.

journal_research.title: Journal Research
journal_research.objective: Read and review articles from current scientific journals.
journal_research.content: New scientific studies are published in scientific journals.

rounding.title: Rounding
rounding.objective: Given a decimal number in standard notation, round to a certain number of decimal places correctly
rounding.note: No whining, people do it wrong all the time!

significant_figures_1.title: Significant Figures 1

significant_figures_1.objective: Given a value in standard or scientific notation, count the number of significant figures in that value.

error_calculation_1.title: Error Calculation 1

significant_figures_2.title: Significant Figures 2

significant_figures_2.objective: Given a value in standard or scientific notation, round to a certain number of significant figures.

error_calculation_2.title: Error Calculation 2
error_calculation_2.subtitle: Calculating Percent Difference and Percent Error
error_calculation_2.objective: Given two numbers, calculate the percent different between those numbers; given a theoretical and determined value, calculate the percent error of a theory.

significant_figures_3.title: Significant Figures 3
significant_figures_3.subtitle: Solving Problems with the Correct Number of Significant Figures
significant_figures_3.objective: Given a simple physics problem whose inputs have different degrees of accuracy, solve the problem and state the answer with the correct number of significant figures.

estimating_error.title: Estimating Error
estimating_error.subtitle: Significant Figures of a Measurement
estimating_error.objective: Given a measurement and method of measuring, estimate the amount of error in that measurement and write how many significant figures would be appropriate to report.

purpose_significant_figures.title: The Purpose of Significant Figures
purpose_significant_figures.objective: Explain why scientists use significant figures; explain why long decimal answers are poor in science

back_of_envelope_calculations.title: Back of the Envelope Calculations
enduring_understandings: When presented with some novel situation or problem,
A good scientist can, in a small amount of space and without a calculator,
figure out an order of magnitude estimate of the answer.

slap_a_chicken.title: How hard do you need to slap a chicken to cook it?

conceptual_conservation_of_energy.title: Conceptual Conservation of Energy
conceptual_conservation_of_energy.note: Eliminate repetitive pods, don't have multiple choice and open response in separate pods.

energy_transfer_1.title: Energy Transfer 1
energy_transfer_1.subtitle: Recognize Energy Types
energy_transfer_1.objective: Recognize single examples of different types of energy
energy_transfer_1.content: There are approximate 10 different types of energy into which we can classify most of the energy in our lives.

state_law_conservation_of_energy.title: State the Law of Conservation of Energy
state_law_conservation_of_energy.objective: State, from memory, the law of conservation of energy.
state_law_conservation_of_energy.content: The Law of Conservation of Energy states that the total energy of the universe remains constant, energy cannot be created or destroyed, it only changes from one type to another.

energy_transfer_2.title: Energy Transfer 2
energy_transfer_2.objective: Recognize processes of 2-3 steps in which energy changes from one type to another; name these processes; draw diagrams depicting the processes
energy_transfer_2.content: Most of the events in our life, such as turning on a light bulb, or eating food and then running, involve energy changing from one type to another

categorize_energy.title: Categorize Energy
categorize_energy.objective: Write the names of different types of energy; categorize each form of energy as kinetic energy or potential energy.
categorize_energy.content: There are several different types of energy into which we can classify most of the energy in our lives; each type of energy can be categorized as kinetic or potential energy

energy_transfer_3.title: Energy Transfer 3
energy_transfer_3.subtitle: Energy From the Sun
energy_transfer_3.objective: Using energy transfer diagrams, connect energy used in your life back to sunlight.
energy_transfer_3.content: The sun is the major source of energy for our food, heat, and light.

energy_transfer_4.title: Energy Transfer 4
energy_transfer_4.subtitle: Electricity
energy_transfer_4.objective: Using energy transfer diagrams, connect energy from an electrical outlet back to sunlight.
energy_transfer_4.content: All of the electrical energy from outlets on earth, save geothermal and nuclear energy, can be traced back to light from the sun.
energy_transfer_4.example: Describe how the energy contained in natural gas is converted to light energy from a light bulb.

energy_transfer_5.title: Energy Transfer 5
energy_transfer_5.subtitle: Efficiency
energy_transfer_5.objective: Draw energy transfer diagrams that a single one source of energy becomes many different types.
energy_transfer_5.content: Energy transfer is never perfectly clean and neat but always accounts for some energy going to different types, particularly thermal energy (heat loss).
energy_transfer_5.notes: The exceptions, which should be noted, are geothermal and nuclear energy.

solar_physics.title: Solar Physics
solar_physics.objective: Describe how the gravitational potential energy of gas and dust in space eventually becomes the light emitted by the sun.
solar_physics.content: Stars are formed by gas and dust in space attracting so strongly that it forms thermonuclear fusion and begins emitting electromagnetic energy.

birth_of_energy.title: The Birth of Energy
birth_of_energy.objective: Connect energy of the earth through the gravitational potential energy of space dust (which would eventually form the sun) back to the creation of energy during the big bang
birth_of_energy.content: Under current cosmological models, all of the energy in the universe can be traced back to some moment in time in which is suddenly appeared, which is named the 'Big Bang.'
birth_of_energy.connections: Requires knowledge of gravitation, nuclear physics, and cosmology

your_address_in_cosmos.title: Your Address in the Cosmos
your_address_in_cosmos.objective: Define planets within solar systems, solar systems within galaxies, galaxies within clusters, etc.
your_address_in_cosmos.content: The earth sits within a solar system, a galaxy, and a cluster of galaxies.

what_is_cosmology.title: What is cosmology?
what_is_cosmology.objective: Define cosmology, differentiate between cosmology and astronomy; give examples of cosmological questions and cosmological texts
what_is_cosmology.content: Cosmology is the science of the entire universe. It deals with questions such as how was the universe created and how will it end.

expansion_of_universe.title: The Expansion of the Universe
expansion_of_universe.objective: Explain evidence that the universe is expanding from the red-shift of far away galaxies.
expansion_of_universe.content: All far away objects are moving farther away. The farther away an objects is, the faster it is moving away. This occurs because space itself is stretching.

cosmological_principle.title: The Cosmological Principle
cosmological_principle.objective: Describe evidence the universe is infinite; define the cosmological principle; give arguments in favor of the cosmological principle;
cosmological_principle.content: The cosmological principle states that the laws of physics are identical at all places in the universe, and the universe is infinite and without a center. No observer has a different view of the universe than any other, and earth cannot be the center of the universe.

infinite_and_expanding.title: Infinite and Expanding?
infinite_and_expanding.objective: Explain how the universe can be both infinite and expanding.
infinite_and_expanding.content: The universe is infinite and is expanding because the space between galaxies is itself stretching.

big_bang.title: The Big Bang
big_bang.objective: Explain how scientists created the big bang theory; properly define the big bang.
big_bang.content: If you follow the progress of the universe backwards, all matter and energy would eventually compress to one point. The moment at which all matter and energy emerged suddenly is referred to as the big bang. The big bang does not represent an explosion.

stages_of_universe.title: Stages of the Universe
stages_of_universe.objective: Explain the stages of the development of the universe according to the big bang theory.
stages_of_universe.content: As the universe expanded, matter took on different forms, from different forms of plasma into our current structure of atoms.

comic_microwave_background.title: The Cosmic Microwave Background
comic_microwave_background.objective: Explain the existence and discovery of the cosmic microwave background; examine how it gives evidence for the big bang theory
comic_microwave_background.content: In all directions, a very faint microwave signals exists as a remnant of the transition of matter from plasma to atoms.

big_bang_limitations.title: Big Bang Limitations
big_bang_limitations.objective: Explain limitations of the big bang theory and open questions within cosmology
big_bang_limitations.content: The big bang theory alone does not completely match observed data and must be modified with theories such as inflationary theory.

your_own_brief_history_of_time.title: Your Own Brief History of Time
your_own_brief_history_of_time.objective: Tell the story of the history of the universe, the solar system, the earth, life on earth, humans, and yourself beginning with the Big Bang and ending with this moment.
your_own_brief_history_of_time.content: We can trace our own lives within the history of the universe to the big bang.
your_own_brief_history_of_time.note: Must incorporate information from physics, chemistry, biology, history, and any other relevant field

alternative_universes.title: Alternative Universes
alternative_universes.objective: Within the big bang theory, imagine how if some variables were different our own experience in the universe would be different.
alternative_universes.content: We do not know why variables, such as the charge to mass ratio of an electron or the speed of light, have the precise values they do. If they were different, the progression of the universe may have been markedly different.

energy_table_1.title: Energy Table 1
energy_table_1.objective: Answer qualitative questions about how KE and GPE change as a ball rolls down a ramp; fill out a box that numerically describes KE and GPE at each time.
energy_table_1.content: As a ball rolls down a ramp, gravitational potential energy converts into kinetic energy.

energy_formulas_1.title: Energy Formulas 1
energy_formulas_1.objective: Solve problems involving the KE and GPE formulas.
energy_formulas_1.content: Formulas for kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy relate these quantities to speed and height, respectively.

memorize_conservation_of_energy.title: Memorize The Conservation of Energy
memorize_conservation_of_energy.objective: Recite the conservation of energy word for word.
memorize_conservation_of_energy.content: The total amount of energy in the universe stays the same. Energy cannot be created or destroyed. It only changes from one type to another.

energy_table_2.title: Energy Table 2
energy_table_2.objective: Fill out a box numerically describing KE and GPE at each time; box requires some inferences as well as mathematical equations; infer information about motion from the table.
energy_table_2.content: Physicists can use the conservation of energy and formulas for kinetic and potential energy together to learn information about an object in motion.

kinetic_potential_energy_graphs_1.title: Kinetic and Potential Energy Graphs 1
kinetic_potential_energy_graphs_1.objective: Make a graph showing kinetic and gravitational potential energy as an object falls or rises.
kinetic_potential_energy_graphs_1.content: Kinetic, potential, and total energy can be represented qualitatively as an objcet moves.

system_language.title: System Language
system_language.objective: Describe changes in energy using the language of systems and work done on a system; Properly describe gravitational potential energy as being part of an object-earth system; properly describe elastic potential energy as being part of an object-spring system
system_language.content: Gravitational potential energy is shared by an object and the planet it is attracted to, which is described as the 'planet-earth system.'

zero_point_height.title: Zero Point Height
zero_point_height.objective: Consider zero point height as a part of the GPE formula
zero_point_height.content: The variable h in the formula for gravitational potential energy is dependent on a physicists choice of a particular zero-point.

roller_coaster_problems.title: Roller Coaster Problems
roller_coaster_problems.objective: Describe the KE and GPE of a roller coaster moving both up and down without a table, solve numerical questions based upon the result
roller_coaster_problems.content: A physicist can gain useful information from considering the exchange of potential and kinetic energy.

energy_table_4.title: Energy Table 4
energy_table_4.subtitle: Horizontal Spring
energy_table_4.objective: Use a table describing KE and EPE to analyze a horizontal spring, make inferences and solve numerical questions based upon the result; define the equilibrium length of a spring; make a table showing how KE and EPE change in a frictionless spring
energy_table_4.content: As a spring moves back and forth, kinetic energy is exchanged for elastic potential energy and vice-versa; a physicist can use this knowledge to gain useful information about the spring system.

energy_table_5.title: Energy Table 5: Heat Loss
energy_table_5.objective: Fill out a table describing KE and GPE of an object moving down a slope including heat loss
energy_table_5.content: As an object moves, air resistance and friction turn kinetic energy into thermal energy (called heat loss); A physicist can quantitatively model how much thermal energy is produced.

energy_formulas_3.title: Energy Formulas 3
energy_formulas_3.subtitle: Dimensional Analysis, Symbolic Solutions, Proportionality
energy_formulas_3.objective: Deduce units of formulas for energy; Symbolically solve the formulas for KE, GPE, and EPE; use proportionality to determine changes in energy as other quantities change.
energy_formulas_3.content: All forms of energy have the same units in terms of kilograms, meters, and seconds; proportionality can be used to easily find quantities of energy.

semi_qualitative_conservation_of_energy.title: Semi-Qualitative Conservation of Energy
semi_qualitative_conservation_of_energy.objective: Answer quantitative questions using the conservation of energy by concept alone without resorting to plugging in numbers.

work_done_on_system.title: Work Done on a System
work_done_on_system.objective: Determine the work done on a system by considering changes in energy.
work_done_on_system.content: Work done on a system is the change in the total energy of that system.

symbolic_energy.title: Symbolic Energy
symbolic_energy.objective: Describe the transfer of the energy within a system symbolically; explain equations derived; use equations derived to find useful equations and functions
symbolic_energy.content: A physicist can derive useful new equations by using the conservation of energy symbolically

vertical_spring_system.title: Vertical Spring System
vertical_spring_system.objective: Numerically analyze change in energy on a system including a mass on a vertical spring in which work is done on the system by an outside force and by friction.
vertical_spring_system.content: A vertical spring system consists of an exchange between kinetic, gravitational potential, and elastic potential energy

algebraic_energy_analysis_1.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 1
algebraic_energy_analysis_1.subtitle: Pendulums
algebraic_energy_analysis_1.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a pendulum system as it swings; write statements regarding the energy of the pendulum-earth system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the pendulum using the Conservation of Energy.
algebraic_energy_analysis_1.content: A pendulum system can be modeled by algebraic functions for position, speed, and energy.

algebraic_energy_analysis_2.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 2
algebraic_energy_analysis_2.subtitle: Horizontal Springs
algebraic_energy_analysis_2.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a horizontal spring system as it moves; write statements regarding the energy of the mass-spring system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the spring using the Conservation of Energy.
algebraic_energy_analysis_2.content: A horizontal spring system can be modeled by algebraic functions for position, speed, and energy.

algebraic_energy_analysis_3.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 3
algebraic_energy_analysis_3.subtitle: Vertical Springs
algebraic_energy_analysis_3.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a vertical spring system as it moves; write statements regarding the energy of the mass-spring-earth system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the spring using the Conservation of Energy.
algebraic_energy_analysis_3.content: A vertical spring system can be modeled by algebraic functions for position, speed, and energy.

spidermans_energy.title: Spiderman's Energy
spidermans_energy.objective: Analyze the potential energy of a fast moving spring that stretches as it falls.
spidermans_energy.content: A physicist can invent a new model for a novel situation, such as a person (Spiderman) swinging from a stretching string.

work_formula.title: The Work Formula
work_formula.objective: Solve for the work done by a force, including in cases where an object does not move.
work_formula.content: Work is equal to force times distance; if an object does not move, no work is done; power is equal to work divided by time elapsed while down that work.

power_formulas.title: Power Formulas
power_formulas.objective: Solve multiple different formulas for the power of an object
power_formulas.content: Power is equal to work divided by time AND equal to energy transferred divided by tiem

defining_mechanical_energy.title: Defining Mechanical Energy
defining_mechanical_energy.objective: Write the definition of mechanical energy, recognize examples of mechanical and non-mechanical energies, sum mechanical energy of objects with several different types of energy.
defining_mechanical_energy.content: Kinetic energy and the forms of potential energy that can be gained by doing work are called mechanical energy; gravitational and elastic potential energy are a component of mechanical energy; chemical, electrochemical, and nuclear potential energies are not a part of mechanical energy.

is_work_done.title: Is work done?
is_work_done.objective: Identify situations in which positive work, negative work, and zero work is done.
is_work_done.content: If an object moves in the direction of the force on an object, positive work is done; if an object moves in the opposite direction as a force on an object, negative work is done; if an object moves in a direction perpendicular to the force on an object, no work is done; if an object does not move no work is done.

weightlifter_problem.title: The Weightlifter Problem
weightlifter_problem.objective: Analyze how work and power are different for weightlifters lifting weights at different speeds.
weightlifter_problem.content: A weightlifter lifting more weight ot a taller height is doing more work; a weightlifter lifting the same weight to the same height but in less time does the same work but has more power.

conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.title: Conservative vs. Non-conservative Forces
conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.objective: Identify conservative and non-conservative forces and explain how they can be analyzed differently.
conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.content: A conservative force does not cause a system to lose mechanical energy; gravity and the elastic force are conservative forces; friction and air resistance are non-conservative forces

work_energy_theorem_1.title: The Work-Energy Theorem 1
work_energy_theorem_1.objective: Create Formulas based on the work-energy theorem and use them to solve dynamics and kinematics problems.
work_energy_theorem_1.content: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the work done a system equals to the change in mechanical energy of a system; physicists can use the work formula to calculate work done and then use this value to calculate quantities of kinetic and/or potential energy.
work_energy_theorem_1.limits: In this quiz, each type of potential energy is considered and the system is not rigorously defined yet.

force_position_graphs_1.title: Force-Position Graphs 1: Calculating Work
force_position_graphs_1.objective: Calculate Work using a force-position graph.
force_position_graphs_1.content: The work done on an object is equal to the area under the curve of a force-position graph of that object.

work_energy_theorem_2.title: The Work-Energy Theorem 2
work_energy_theorem_2.objective: Create Formulas based on the work-energy theorem and use them to solve dynamics and kinematics problems.
work_energy_theorem_2.content: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the work done a system equals to the change in mechanical energy of a system; physicists can use the work formula to calculate work done and then use this value to calculate quantities of kinetic and/or potential energy.
work_energy_theorem_2.limits: In this quiz, each type of potential energy is considered and the system is not rigorously defined yet.

multiple_viewpoints_1.title: Multiple Viewpoints 1
multiple_viewpoints_1.subtitle: Rising and Falling
multiple_viewpoints_1.objective: When an object is dropped downward, thrown upward, or lifted upward, qualitatively show that the work-energy theorem is followed no matter how the system is defined.
multiple_viewpoints_1.content: When using the work-energy theorem, a physicist defines a specific system and all forces internal and external to that system; by redefining the system, the physicist changes which forces and which types of potential energy are used in the analysis

force_position_graphs_2.title: Force-Position Graphs 2: Work-Energy Theorem
force_position_graphs_2.objective: Use a force-position graph together with the work-energy theorem to find dynamic and kinematic quantities.
force_position_graphs_2.content: A physicist, by understanding the definition of work and the work-energy theorem, can learn useful quantities from a force-position graph of an object.

multiple_viewpoints_2.title: Multiple Viewpoints 2: Comet
multiple_viewpoints_2.objective: Analyze, algebraically and graphically, a comet orbiting the sun with different definitions of the system and the surroundings.
multiple_viewpoints_2.content: When using the work-energy theorem, a physicist defines a specific system and all forces internal and external to that system; by redefining the system, the physicist changes which forces and which types of potential energy are used in the analysis

prove_work_energy_theorem.title: Prove the Work Energy Theorem: Special Case
prove_work_energy_theorem.objective: Algebraically prove the work-energy theorem when acceleration is constant.
prove_work_energy_theorem.content: For an object moving with a constant acceleration, the work-energy theorem can be demonstrated by combining Newton's Laws of motion with the kinematic equations.

define_potential_energy.title: Define Potential Energy
define_potential_energy.objective: Define potential energy using the concept of work, conservative and non-conservative forces.
define_potential_energy.content: The formulas we use for potential energy can be derived from the formula for work and the conservation of energy.

multiple_viewpoints_3.title: Multiple Viewpoints 3: Spidey String
multiple_viewpoints_3.objective: Analyze, algebraically and graphically, Spiderman swinging from his spidey-string with different definitions of the system and surroundings.
multiple_viewpoints_3.content: As Spiderman swings from building to building, he gains and loses kinetic energy, his string gains and loses elastic potential energy, and the spiderman-earth system gains and loses gravitational potential energy; a physicist can analyze this motion using multiple different systems as a point of view and find the same underlying result.

potential_energy_functions.title: Potential Energy Functions
potential_energy_functions.notes: This is actually a step towards the field of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.

position_graphs_motion_maps.title: Position Graphs and Motion Maps
position_graphs_motion_maps.objective: Identify position-time graphs and motion maps for single-step descriptions of motion.
position_graphs_motion_maps.content: Position-time graphs and motion maps are two ways to represent how something is moving.

velocity_acceleration_graphs.title: Velocity and Acceleration Graphs
velocity_acceleration_graphs.objective: Identify velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs for single-step descriptions of motion
velocity_acceleration_graphs.content: Velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs are two other ways to represent how something is moving.

kinematic_graph_connections.title: Kinematic Graph Connections
kinematic_graph_connections.objective: For single-step descriptions of motion, identify position, velocity, and acceleration graphs that describe that motion; for a given position, velocity, or acceleration graph, identify two other graphs that describe the same motion.
kinematic_graph_connections.content: Position-time graphs, velocity-time graphs, and acceleration-time graphs can represent the same example of motion.

kinematic_graph_comparisons_1.title: Kinematic Graph Comparisons 1
kinematic_graph_comparisons_1.objective: Qualitatively compare different curves and lines on kinematic graphs.
kinematic_graph_comparisons_1.content: Characteristics of a kinematic graph, such as its slope or shape, can show differences in how an object moves.

kinematics_definitions.title: Kinematics Definitions
kinematics_definitions.objective: Define the terms kinematics, qualitative, quantitative, position, velocity, and acceleration.
kinematics_definitions.content: The goal of qualitative kinematics is to determine how an object moves without determining why.

story_to_graph_selection_1.title: Story to Graph Selection 1
story_to_graph_selection_1.objective: Given a story describing motion with several unique steps of accelerated, decelerated, constant velocity, and zero motion; identify position, velocity, acceleration, and time graphs that describe that motion.
story_to_graph_selection_1.content: Kinematic graphs can represent not just motion in one step but motion in several steps, even demonstrating a story.

kinematic_graph_comparisons_2.title: Kinematic Graph Comparisons 2
kinematic_graph_comparisons_2.objective: Qualitatively Compare different curves and lines on kinematic graphs.
kinematic_graph_comparisons_2.content: Characteristics of a kinematic graph, such as its slope or shape, can show differences in how an object moves.

story_to_graph_selection_2.title: Story to Graph Selection 2
story_to_graph_selection_2.objective: Given a story describing motion with several unique steps of accelerated, decelerated, constant velocity, and zero motion; identify position, velocity, acceleration, and time graphs that describe that motion.
story_to_graph_selection_2.content: Kinematic graphs can represent not just motion in one step but motion in several steps, even demonstrating a story.

position_graph_connection.title: Position Graph Connection
position_graph_connection.objective: Given a qualitative position-time graph showing several unique steps of motion, write a story that could be described by this position time graph and draw corresponding velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs.
position_graph_connection.content: The information in a position-time graph can be represented in words or in other kinematic graphs.

velocity_graph_connection.title: Velocity Graph Connection
velocity_graph_connection.objective: Given a qualitative velocity-time graph showing several unique steps of motion, write a story that could be described by the velocity-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and acceleration-time graphs.
velocity_graph_connection.content: The information in a velocity-time graph can be represented in words or in other kinematic graphs.

acceleration_graph_connection.title: Acceleration Graph Connection
acceleration_graph_connection.objective: Given a qualitative acceleration-time graph showing several unique steps of motion, write a story that could be described by the acceleration-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and velocity-time graphs.
acceleration_graph_connection.content: The information in an acceleration-time graph can be represented in words or in other kinematic graphs.

acceleration_graph_connection_2.title: Acceleration Graph Connection 2
acceleration_graph_connection_2.objective: Given a qualitative and more complex acceleration-time graph showing several unique steps of motion, write a story that could be described by the acceleration-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and velocity-time graphs; develop different stories by changing the initial conditions of the graph.
acceleration_graph_connection_2.content: The information in a highly complex acceleration-time graph can be represented in words or in other kinematic graphs; acceleration graphs contain no information regarding initial velocity.

qualitative_kinematics_advanced.title: Qualitative Kinematics Advanced
qualitative_kinematics_advanced.objective: Invent a highly complex description of motion, and then create kinematic graphs that match the description.
qualitative_kinematics_advanced.content: Kinematic graphs can represent extremely complex descriptions of motion.

forward_kinematics_quantitative.title: Forward Kinematics Quantitative
enduring_understandings: Quantitative modeling of motion is at the core of physics.
Creating mathematical graphs, equations, and functions that accurately describe how an object moves.

speed_formula.title: The Speed Formula
speed_formula.objective: Solve problems using the formula relating distance, speed, and time; always write the appropriate units for distance, speed, and time.
speed_formula.content: Distance is equal to speed times time.

acceleration_formula.title: The Acceleration Formula
acceleration_formula.objective: Solve for acceleration using its definition.
acceleration_formula.content: Acceleration is equal to change in velocity divided by change in time.

kinematic_equations_1.title: Kinematic Equations 1
kinematic_equations_1.subtitle: Kinematic Equations with Information Given
kinematic_equations_1.objective: Solve 1-2 step numerical algebraic problems with the kinematic equations with equations and information given.
kinematic_equations_1.content: The four kinematic equations relate the five kinematic variables for an object moving with a constant acceleration.
parameters: Information is presented in very straightforward language.
Problems involve 1 or 2 algebraic steps to solve.

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_1.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 1
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_1.subtitle: Learning Information from Kinematic Graphs at a Constant Velocity
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_1.objective: From a quantitative kinematic graph, gain information such as velocity and displacement.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_1.content: The slope of a position-time graph is the velocity; the area under the curve of a velocity-time graph is the displacement

kinematic_equations_2.title: Kinematic Equations 2
kinematic_equations_2.subtitle: All Four Together
kinematic_equations_2.objective: Solve numerical algebraic problems with the kinematic equations; use all four kinematic equations interchangeably; know the acceleration of a falling object.
kinematic_equations_2.content: The four kinematic equations relate the five kinematic variables for an object moving with a constant acceleration. They can be applied to problems of varying difficulty.
parameters: Information is presented in realistic language
Problems involve no more than 3 algebraic steps to solve

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_2.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 2
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_2.subtitle: Connecting Position and Velocity Graphs
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_2.objective: Given a position-time graph showing stepwise motion with different constant velocities, draw a velocity-time graph; given a velocity-time graph showing stepwise motion with different constant velocities, draw a position-time graph; explain the process.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_2.content: Physicists use the relationship amongst velocity and displacement in quantitative kinematic graphs to draw velocity-time graphs for a corresponding position-time graphs and vice versa.

kinematic_equations_3.title: Kinematic Equations 3
kinematic_equations_3.subtitle: Real World Problems
kinematic_equations_3.objective: Solve numerical algebraic problems in which information is not explicitly given but must be inferred
kinematic_equations_3.content: The four kinematic equations can be used to real-world problems if a physicist can break real-world information down to the kinematic variables.

memorize_kinematic_equations.title: Memorize the Kinematic Equations (and other things)
memorize_kinematic_equations.content: By recalling the four kinematic equations with automaticity, a physicist can more easily approach much more challenging problems.

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_3.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 3
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_3.subtitle: Learning Information from Accelerating Kinematic Graphs
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_3.objective: From a quantitative kinematic graph, gain information such as acceleration, initial and final velocity.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_3.content: A physicist can learn kinematic quantities from a quantitative kinematic graph, and then relate them using the kinematic equations.

kinematic_equations_4.title: Kinematic Equations 4
kinematic_equations_4.subtitle: Stepwise Kinematic Equations
kinematic_equations_4.objective: Numerically solve the kinematic equations for step-wise motion.
kinematic_equations_4.content: The kinematic equations can be when some object changes acceleration but its motion can be broken to several unique steps of independent motion.

kinematic_equations_as_functions.title: The Kinematic Equations as Functions
kinematic_equations_as_functions.objectives: Write the kinematic equations as functions; explain this transition

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4A.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 4A
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4A.objective: Given a quantitative position-time graph for single-step motion, draw correct quantitative velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4A.content: The kinematic equations and geometric relationships can gain information about velocity and acceleration from a position-time graph.

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4B.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 4B
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4B.objective: Given a quantitative velocity-time graph for single-step motion, draw correct quantitative position-time and acceleration-time graphs.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4B.content: The kinematic equations and geometric relationships can gain information about displacement and acceleration from a velocity-time graph.

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4C.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 4C
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4C.objective: Given a quantitative acceleration-time graph for single-step motion, draw correct quantitative position-time and velocity-time graphs.
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_4C.content: The kinematic equations and geometric relationships can gain information about displacement and change in velocity from an acceleration-time graph.

kinematic_equations_symbolic.title: Kinematic Equations Symbolic
kinematic_equations_symbolic.objective: Solve the kinematic equations symbolically and defend answers using dimensional analysis.
kinematic_equations_symbolic.content: New kinematic formulas can be derived by solving the kinematic equations symbolically

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_5.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 5
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_5.subtitle: Stepwise Kinematic Graphs
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_5.objective: For a quantitative description of step-wise motion, create three quantitative kinematic graphs.

derive_kinematic_equations.title: Derive the Kinematic Equations
derive_kinematic_equations.objective: Use the core mathematical principles of kinematics to prove each of the four kinematic equations is true under the special case of constant acceleration.

fundamental_theorem_calculus.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: Special Case
fundamental_theorem_calculus.objective: Using only algebra and a conceptual understanding of calculus, demonstrate the fundamental theorem of calculus for the special case of motion with a constant acceleration by using graphs, defining derivatives and integrals, and relating the graphs to the kinematic equations.

flying_to_mars.title: Flying to Mars
flying_to_mars.objective: Demonstrate using kinematic equations and graphs how a spaceship can get to Mars faster through constant acceleration and deceleration.

position_graphs_2.title: Position Graphs 2
position_graphs_2.subtitle: Forward and Backward Position Graphs
position_graphs_2.objective: Create qualitative position graphs for objects moving in two different directions around an origin; define an origin and a positive and negative direction

velocity_acceleration_graphs_2.title: Velocity and Acceleration Graphs 2
velocity_acceleration_graphs_2.subtitle: Two Direction Velocity and Acceleration Graphs
velocity_acceleration_graphs_2.objective: Using qualitative velocity and acceleration graphs, identify when an object is speeding up and slowing down and what direction an object is moving

kinematic_graph_connections_2.title: Kinematic graphs Connections 2
kinematic_graph_connections_2.subtitle: Connecting graphs of two direction motion
kinematic_graph_connections_2.objective: Relate three different types of kinematic graphs for objects moving with a constant acceleration in either direction.

kinematic_graph_comparison_3.title: Kinematic Graph Comparison 3
kinematic_graph_comparison_3.objective: Compare different kinematic graphs for objects moving in different directions; answer questions such as which one is moving faster etc.

direction_reversal_origin_relocation.title: Direction Reversal and Origin Relocation
direction_reversal_origin_relocation.objective: Given all types of kinematic graphs, show how the graphs must change if a physicist decides to reverse the positive and negative direction and/or change the location of the origin.

story_to_graph_selection_3.title: Story to Graph Selection 3
story_to_graph_selection_3.subtitle: (The Traffic Light Problem)
story_to_graph_selection_3.objective: Given a story, select the position-time, acceleration-time, and velocity-time graphs that reflect the story.

kinematic_graph_comparison_4.title: Kinematic Graph Comparison 4
kinematic_graph_comparison_4.objective: Compare different kinematic graphs for objects moving in different directions; answer questions such as which one is accelerating faster etc.

story_to_graph_selection_4.title: Story to Graph Selection 4
story_to_graph_selection_4.objective: Given a story, select the position-time, acceleration-time, and velocity-time graphs that reflect the story.

position_graph_connection_2.title: Position Graph Connection 2
position_graph_connection_2.subtitle: Position Graph Connection in two directions
position_graph_connection_2.objective: Given a qualitative position-time graph of an object moving in two directions, write a relevant story for that position-time graph and draw corresponding velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs

velocity_graph_connection_2.title: Velocity Graph Connection 2
velocity_graph_connection_2.subtitle: Velocity Graph Connection in two directions
velocity_graph_connection_2.objective: Given a qualitative velocity-time graph of an object moving in two directions, write a relevant story for that velocity-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and acceleration-time graphs

acceleration_graph_connection_3.title: Acceleration Graph Connection 3
acceleration_graph_connection_3.subtitle: Acceleration Graph Connection in two directions
acceleration_graph_connection_3.objective: Given a qualitative acceleration-time graph of an object moving in two directions with initial velocity of zero, write a relevant story for that acceleration-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and velocity-time graphs.

velocity_graph_connection_3.title: Velocity Graph Connection 3
velocity_graph_connection_3.subtitle: Velocity Graph Connection in two directions and multiple initial positions
velocity_graph_connection_3.objective: Given a qualitative velocity-time graph of an object moving in two directions, write a relevant story for that velocity-time graph and draw corresponding position-time and acceleration-time graphs; complete this task for several different initial positions

acceleration_graph_connection_4.title: Acceleration Graph Connection 4
acceleration_graph_connection_4.subtitle: Acceleration Graph Connection in two directions and multiple initial velocities
acceleration_graph_connection_4.objective: Given a qualitative acceleration-time graph of an object moving in two directions, write a relevant story for that graph and draw corresponding velocity-time and position-time graphs; complete this task for initial velocity zero, positive initial velocity, and negative initial velocity

qualitative_kinematics_advanced_2.title: Qualitative Kinematics Advanced 2
qualitative_kinematics_advanced_2.objective: Given a complex description of motion, write a story that comprises this motion, and draw relevant position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs; define an origin and a positive and negative direction within the story

very_basic_vectors_scalars.title: Very basic vectors and scalars
very_basic_vectors_scalars.objective: Define vectors and scalars; identify basic vectors and scalars.

distance_vs_displacement.title: Distance vs. Displacement
distance_vs_displacement.objective: Calculate distance and displacement for one-dimensional motion.

quantitative_kinematic_graphs_6.title: Quantitative Kinematic Graphs 6
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_6.subtitle: Information from Position and Velocity graphs in 2-directions
quantitative_kinematic_graphs_6.objective: Find speed and/or displacement from position and velocity graphs for objects moving in two-directions.

average_speed_vs_average_velocity.title: Average Speed vs. Average Velocity
average_speed_vs_average_velocity.objective: Calculate average speed and average velocity in simple situations; know that average speed does not include direction and average velocity does; identify situations when average velocity is zero.

distance_displacement_position.title: Distance, Displacement, and Position (Nick the Knight)
distance_displacement_position.objective: Define an origin, positive direction, and negative direction; calculate distance, displacement, and position in multi-step motion

kinematic_equations_5.title: Kinematic Equations 5
kinematic_equations_5.subtitle: The first kinematic equation in two directions
kinematic_equations_5.objective: Solve the first kinematic equation in two-directions; use relevant quantities to identify what direction an object is moving and whether is is speeding up or slowing down.

kinematic_graphs_7.title: Kinematic Graphs 7
kinematic_graphs_7.subtitle: Connect and Interpret position and velocity graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_7.objective: Given a velocity-time graph of an object moving in a constant velocity in multiple directions, draw a corresponding position-time graph; given a position-time graph of an object moving in a constatn velocity in two directions, draw a relevant velocity time graph; interpret the graphs for relevant information such as which direction an object is moving
kinematic_graphs_7.notes: Level 2 is crowded, beef this up and make it truly level 3

kinematic_equations_6.title: Kinematic Equations 6
kinematic_equations_6.subtitle: Turn Around Problems
kinematic_equations_6.objective: Solve all kinematic equations in two-directions; use relevant quantities to identify what direction an object is moving and whether is is speeding up or slowing down.

kinematic_equations_7.title: Kinematic Equations 7
kinematic_equations_7.subtitle: Real world kinematics in two directions
kinematic_equations_7.objective: Solve real world problems with an object moving at a constant acceleration in two directions, including pop-up problems; interpret results for relevant information

kinematic_graphs_8.title: Kinematic Graphs 8
kinematic_graphs_8.subtitle: Information from Kinematic Graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_8.objective: Find kinematic quantities from a kinematic graph of an object moving in two directions.

kinematic_equations_8.title: Kinematic Equations 8
kinematic_equations_8.subtitle: Stepwise kinematic equations in two directions
kinematic_equations_8.objective: Use the kinematic equations to analyze stepwise motion in two different directions; solve for average speed and average velocity in more complex situations.

kinematic_graphs_9A.title: Kinematic Equations 9A
kinematic_graphs_9A.subtitle: Position to other graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_9A.objective: Given a position-time graph of an object moving in two different directions, draw a corresponding velocity-time graph and acceleration-time graph; includes only constant acceleration motion

kinematic_graphs_9B.title: Kinematic Equations 9B
kinematic_graphs_9B.subtitle: Velocity to other graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_9B.objective: Given a velocity-time graph of an object moving in two different directions, draw a corresponding position-time graph and acceleration-time graph; includes only constant acceleration motion

kinematic_graphs_9C.title: Kinematic Equations 9C
kinematic_graphs_9C.subtitle: Acceleration to other graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_9C.objective: Given an acceleration-time graph of an object moving in two different directions, draw a corresponding position-time graph and velocity-time graph; includes only constant acceleration motion

kinematic_graphs_10.title: Kinematic Graphs 10
kinematic_graphs_10.subtitle: Stepwise kinematic graphs in two directions
kinematic_graphs_10.objective: Given a description of stepwise motion of an object moving two-directions, draw position-time graph, velocity-time graph, and acceleration-time graph for the object; each step has constant acceleration

derive_kinematic_equations_2.title: Derive the Kinematic Equations 2
derive_kinematic_equations_2.subtitle: Derive the kinematic equations in two directions
derive_kinematic_equations_2.objective: Demonstrate that the derivation of the kinematic equations from unit 102 still applies when an object's velocity-time function crosses the y-axis

fundamental_theorem_of_calculus_2.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus 2
fundamental_theorem_of_calculus_2.subtitle: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus in two directions
fundamental_theorem_of_calculus_2.objective: Demonstrate that the fundamental theorem of calculus still connects the three main kinematic quantities when the velocity-time function crosses the y-axis.

bungee_jumper.title: The bungee jumper
bungee_jumper.objective: Create a quantitative kinematic model for a bungee jumper.

galilean_relativity_1.title: Galilean Relativity 1: One-Dimensional Problems
galilean_relativity_1.objective: Determine the motion of two moving objects relative to each other.

reference_frames_1.title: Reference Frames 1
reference_frames_1.objective: Define reference frames; define velocity as relative to a particular reference frame.

galilean_relativity_2.title: Galilean Relativity 2: Crossing the River (2-D)
galilean_relativity_2.objective: Determine the motion of objects in two dimensions relative to particular reference frames
galilean_relativity_2.example: Cross a river and end up in the correct spot on the opposite shore while accounting for current in the river.

jumping_out_of_car.title: Jumping out of a Car
jumping_out_of_car.objective: Use reference frames to analyze what happens when jumping out of a car.

reference_frames_2.title: Reference Frames 2
reference_frames_2.objective: Define and identify inertial and non-inertial reference frames.

cup_on_dashboard_two_points_view.title: Cup on the Dashboard from Two Points of View
cup_on_dashboard_two_points_view.objective: Analyze straight line accelerated motion in a car from the point of view of inertial and non-inertial reference frames.

galileos_proof_sun_roof_cannon.title: Galileo's Proof and the Sun Roof Cannon
galileos_proof_sun_roof_cannon.objective: Use knowledge of physics within each reference frame to argue that it is possible for the earth to move while humans live without feeling its motion; analyze the motion of an object shot vertically out from a car.
galileos_proof_sun_roof_cannon.note: Sun Roof cannon problem included in this pod.

earths_reference_frame.title: Earth's Reference Frame
earths_reference_frame.objective: Analyze the earth has a non-inertial reference frame; analyze a Foucault pendulum.

non_inertial_reference_frames_circular_m.title: Non-Inertial Reference Frames in Circular Motion
non_inertial_reference_frames_circular_m.objective: Analyze non-inertial reference frames moving in circular from the point of view of the motion object and the earth; examples include a gravitron amusement park ride or a loop de loop.

quantitative_sun_roof_cannon.title: Quantitative Sun Roof Cannon
quantitative_sun_roof_cannon.objective: Quantitatively analyze an object shot upward out of a car.

three_types_motion.title: Three Types of Motion
three_types_motion.objective: Understand the difference between three different types of motion: constant velocity, uniformly accelerating, and non-uniformly accelerating
three_types_motion.content: Constant velocity motion is analyzed with the speed formula, uniformly accelerated motion is analyzed with the four kinematic equations, and non-uniformly accelerated motion is analyzed with calculus.

falling_1.title: Falling 1
falling_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
falling_1.objective: Solve numeric problems about objects falling down and objects thrown downwards.
falling_1.content: Objects falling downwards have an acceleration of 9/8 m/s^2 downwards and follow the four kinematic equations

parabolic_arcs.title: Parabolic Arcs
parabolic_arcs.objective: Draw qualitative diagrams of objects in projectile motion; define free-fall
parabolic_arcs.content: All objects in projectile motion follow downward facing parabolic arcs; all objects that have only gravity acting on them, no matter what direction they are moving, are in free-fall.

falling_2.title: Falling 2
falling_2.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy Analysis
falling_2.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object falling downward; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object falling downward; demonstrate how an object falling downward follows the conservation of energy.
falling_2.content: Physicists can analyze an object falling downward through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

pop_up_1.title: Pop-Up 1
pop_up_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
pop_up_1.objective: Solve numeric problems about objects falling down and objects thrown directly upwards.
pop_up_1.content: Objects thrown upwards have an acceleration of 9/8 m/s^2 downwards, have an initial velocity that is upwards, and follow the four kinematic equations

falling_3.title: Falling 3
falling_3.subtitle: Functional and Algebraic Analysis
falling_3.objective: Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is falling; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
falling_3.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object falling downwards.

pop_up_2.title: Pop-Up 2
pop_up_2.subtitle: Numeric Analysis with Quadratic Equation
pop_up_2.objective: Solve numerical pop-up problems which require the use of the quadratic equation.
pop_up_2.content: When an object is thrown directly upwards and lands at a different vertical position than it began, a physicist must use the quadratic formula to solve the necessary kinematic equations and describe the motion of the ball.

pop_up_3.title: Pop-Up 3
pop_up_3.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy-based Analysis
pop_up_3.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object thrown directly upward; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object thrown directly upward; demonstrate how an object thrown directly upward follows the conservation of energy.
pop_up_3.content: Physicists can analyze an object thrown directly upward through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

horizontal_launch_1.title: Horizontal Launch 1
horizontal_launch_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
horizontal_launch_1.objective: Solve for important kinematic quantities when an object is launched horizontally.
horizontal_launch_1.content: When an object is launched horizontally, it moves at a constant speed in the horizontal dimension and accelerates downward in the vertical dimension; physicists can use the kinematic equations to analyze the motion of this object.

bullet_drop_conundrum.title: Bullet Drop Conundrum
bullet_drop_conundrum.objective: Explain, in words, how a bullet dropped and a bullet fired from a gun reach the ground at the same time; analyze the an object launched upward out of the sunroof of a moving car.
bullet_drop_conundrum.content: Motion in the horizontal dimension does not affect motion in the vertical dimension, therefore an object fired horizontally, such as a bullet, falls at precisely the same rate as an object merely dropped

horizontal_launch_2.title: Horizontal Launch 2
horizontal_launch_2.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy Analysis
horizontal_launch_2.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object fired horizontally; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object fired horizontally; demonstrate how an object fired horizontally follows the conservation of energy.
horizontal_launch_2.content: Physicists can analyze an object fired horizontally through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

cannon_problems_1.title: Cannon Problems 1
cannon_problems_1.subtitle: Concepts and Numeric Analysis
cannon_problems_1.objective: Conceptually explain the motion in each dimension of an object launched at an angle; use this information to solve for relevant numeric quantities.
cannon_problems_1.content: An object fired at an angle moves forward with a constant velocity in the horizontal dimension and moves identically to an object thrown directly upward in the vertical dimension.

cannon_problems_2.title: Cannon Problems 2
cannon_problems_2.subtitle: On Different Levels
cannon_problems_2.objective: Solve a cannon problem in which the cannonball lands on a different vertical level than it began.
cannon_problems_2.content: When a cannonball fired at an angle lands on a different vertical level than where it began, a physicist must use the quadratic formula to determine necessary kinematic quantities.

pop_up_4.title: Pop-Up 4: Symbolic Algebra
pop_up_4.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
pop_up_4.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is thrown directly into the air; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is thrown directly upward; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
pop_up_4.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object thrown directly upwards.

horizontal_launch_3.title: Horizontal Launch 3
horizontal_launch_3.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
horizontal_launch_3.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is fired horizontally; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is fired horizontally; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
horizontal_launch_3.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object fired horizontally.

cannon_problems_3.title: Cannon Problems 3
cannon_problems_3.subtitle: Kinematic and Dynamic Analysis
cannon_problems_3.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object fired at an angle; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object fired at an angle; demonstrate how an object fired at an angle follows the conservation of energy.
cannon_problems_3.content: Physicists can analyze an object fired at an angle through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

banana_cannon.title: The Banana Cannon
banana_cannon.objective: Qualitatively explain how gravity affects horizontally moving and non-horizontally moving objects in the same way and apply this principle to simply aiming a cannon at a falling target with a cannon.
banana_cannon.content: A cannon is aimed directly at a target that begins falling immediately when the cannon fires; the cannon will always strike the target because gravity affects the projectile and the target in the same way.

cannon_problems_4.title: Cannon Problems 4
cannon_problems_4.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
cannon_problems_4.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is fired at an angle; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is fired at an angle; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
cannon_problems_4.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object fired at an angle.

aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.title: Aim a cannon with laser pointers.
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.objective: Determine a method to aim a cannon and expect a direct hit with laser pointers.
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.content: With multiple angles pointing to a particular object, physicists can use trigonometry and geometry to locate a particular object in 1-D, 2-D, or 3-D space
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.note: Connected to the 'placing an object in three-dimensional space' problem from the geometry unit.

wide_receiver_motion.title: Wide Receiver in Motion
wide_receiver_motion.objective: Devise a model that mathematical depicts how a quarterback hits a wide receiver running quickly with a parabolic pass.
wide_receiver_motion.content: Through careful mathematical analysis, a physicist can create a mathematical model that can guide someone to accomplish a complex task, such as hitting a moving target with a projectile motion.

free_body_diagrams_1.title: Free-Body Diagrams 1
free_body_diagrams_1.objective: Recognize the forces in the most common free-body diagrams.
free_body_diagrams_1.content: In free-body diagrams, all forces are represented as arrows showing the direction that force acts; the most common forces in our lives are gravity, normal forces, applied forces, friction, and tension.

newtons_third_law_1.title: Newton's Third Law 1
newtons_third_law_1.objective: State Newton's Third Law and recognize examples of how it applies.
newtons_third_law_1.content: Newton's Third Law states that if A exerts a force on B, B exerts a force on A with equal magnitude and opposite direction.

free_body_diagrams_2.title: Free-Body Diagrams 2
free_body_diagrams_2.objective: Draw from memory the most common free-body diagrams; identify agent and object of each force.
free_body_diagrams_2.content: The most common free-body diagrams include a person not moving, an object being pushed, and an object being lifted up; every force has an agent and an object.

newtons_third_law_2.title: Newton's Third Law 2
newtons_third_law_2.objective: State Newton's Third Law and write examples of how it applies; in particular describe how Newton's Laws apply to walking.
newtons_third_law_2.content: Newtons Third Law allows humans to move by pushing off a surface, and allows a rocket to move by pushing material downward.

interaction_diagrams.title: Interaction Diagrams
interaction_diagrams.objective: Draw interaction diagrams for common dynamic situations
interaction_diagrams.content: An interaction diagram shows a line between interacting objects; each line represents a force

reaction_force_weight.title: The Reaction Force of Weight
reaction_force_weight.objective: Properly use the terms gravity and weight; properly identify the direction of the force of weight; identify the reaction force to weight
reaction_force_weight.content: Physicists use the term weight to describe the force of gravity on a planet; the directions humans call downward is actually inward, towards the center of the earth; the reaction force of our weight is a force we exert on the earth.

free_body_diagrams_3.title: Free-Body Diagrams 3
free_body_diagrams_3.subtitle: Identify Action-Reaction Force Pairs
free_body_diagrams_3.objective: Draw free-body diagrams that contain multiple interacting items; identify the name and agent of each force; identify action reaction pairs and balanced force pairs; differentiate between action-reaction force pairs and balanced force pairs
free_body_diagrams_3.content: When drawing a free-body diagram, always identify the name, direction, object and agent of any force; forces always come in pairs called action-reaction pairs; in an action reaction-pair, the object of one force is the agent of the paired force, and the direction of the paired forces are opposite

free_body_diagrams_4.title: Free-Body Diagrams 4
free_body_diagrams_4.subtitle: Identify More Action-Reaction Force Pairs
free_body_diagrams_4.objective: Draw free-body diagrams that contain multiple interacting items; identify the name and agent of each force; identify action reaction pairs and balanced force pairs; differentiate between action-reaction force pairs and balanced force pairs
free_body_diagrams_4.content: When drawing a free-body diagram, always identify the name, direction, object and agent of any force; forces always come in pairs called action-reaction pairs; in an action reaction-pair, the object of one force is the agent of the paired force, and the direction of the paired forces are opposite
free_body_diagrams_4.note: 2 more questions on the same topic as 3A

subatomic_contact_forces.title: Subatomic Contact Forces
subatomic_contact_forces.objective: Relate contact forces to electrostatic forces. Relate Newton's Third Law to these electrostatic forces.
subatomic_contact_forces.content: Contact forces and applied forces are in fact electrostatic forces acting between subatomic particles of two objects.

lazy_donkey_paradox.title: The Lazy Donkey Paradox
lazy_donkey_paradox.objective: Defend how Newton's Third Law still applies when an object is broken by a force.
lazy_donkey_paradox.content: Newton's Third Law seems to imply that no object may ever move because two forces always cancel each other out (a paradox), but it does not because the action and reaction forces act on two different objects.

system_free_body_diagrams.title: System free-body diagrams
system_free_body_diagrams.objective: Draw free-body diagrams that contain multiple interacting items; identify the name and agent of each force; identify action reaction pairs and balanced force pairs; combine free-body diagrams to create systems and identify internal and external forces within the system.
system_free_body_diagrams.content: Systems can be created by combining all of the forces acting on an object; forces internal to a system are always action-reaction pairs.

newtons_third_law_3.title: Newtons Third Law 3
newtons_third_law_3.subtitle: Forces as a Duality
newtons_third_law_3.objective: Complete a series of objectives related to more abstract applications of Newton's Third Law.
newtons_third_law_3.content: As students develop more in depth knowledge of physics, they should see pairs of forces not as one action and a separate reaction but as two forces that always exist together in a duality.
notes: Restate Newton's Third Law in which forces are not 'actions' and 'reactions' but always come in equal pairs.
Show how Newton's Third Law applies to gravity on earth.
Relate contact forces to electrostatic forces and use this relationship to defend Newton's Third Law for contact forces.

simplest_free_body_diagram.title: The Simplest Free-Body Diagram
simplest_free_body_diagram.objective: Explain common misconceptions related to the free-body diagram of a stationary object.
simplest_free_body_diagram.content: The free-body diagram of a block on a table shows normal force upwards and gravity downwards; the normal force exerted by the table cannot be observed but can be inferred; these two forces are not an action-reaction pair because they act on the same object.

breaking_boards.title: Breaking Boards
breaking_boards.objective: Defend how Newton's Third Law still applies when an object is broken by a force
breaking_boards.content: All objects have a maximum value of force they can absorb before breaking, and you cannot apply a force greater than that value to any object, even if you are able.

finding_net_force.title: Finding Net Force
finding_net_force.subtitle: Finding Net Force in One Dimension
finding_net_force.objective: Given a 1-dimensional quantitative free-body diagram, determine the magnitude and direction of net force acting on an object.
finding_net_force.content: Net force is calculated from a quantitative free-body diagram of an object.

newtons_second_law.title: Newton's Second Law
newtons_second_law.subtitle: Using Newton's Second Law Numerically
newtons_second_law.objective: Use Newton's Second Law to solve numeric problems.
newtons_second_law.content: Newton's Second Law relates the mass of an object, the acceleration of that object, and the net force acting on that object.

finding_acceleration.title: Finding Acceleration
finding_acceleration.subtitle: Finding Acceleration from a Free-Body Diagram
finding_acceleration.objective: Given the mass of an object and several forces acting on that object in one dimension, determine the acceleration of the object.
finding_acceleration.content: A physicist finds acceleration of an object by first finding net force from a quantitative free-body diagram, then finding acceleration from Newton's Second Law.

friction_1.title: Friction 1
friction_1.subtitle: Static vs. Kinetic Friction
friction_1.objective: Recognize when and how friction is applied; differentiate between two different types of friction.
friction_1.content: Kinetic friction acts on objects that are moving; static friction acts on objects that are not moving.

doing_nothing.title: The Dynamics of Doing Nothing
doing_nothing.objective: Carefully analyze the free-body diagram of a stationary object
doing_nothing.content: In a stationary object, gravity is downward and normal force is upward and their magnitudes are equal because normal force is constraint force.

block_dragging_1.title: Block Dragging 1
block_dragging_1.subtitle: Dragging a Block Without Friction
block_dragging_1.objective: Given a block of a certain mass, draw a free-body diagram of the block when it is not moving or being pushed on a surfaced without friction; determine the net force and acceleration of the block.
block_dragging_1.content: Gravity, normal force, and applied force act on a block being dragged; by understanding these forces a physicist can understand the motion of the block.

find_missing_force.title: Find The Missing Force
find_missing_force.objective: Given a free-body diagram and the net force and/or an acceleration and mass, identify the magnitude and direction of an unknown force in a problem.
find_missing_force.content: A physicist sometimes must find a particular force to find the net force acting on a block.

block_dragging_2.title: Block Dragging 2
block_dragging_2.subtitle: Dragging With Kinetic Friction
block_dragging_2.objective: For a block moving on a surface with kinetic friction; draw a free-body diagram of the block, determine the acceleration of coefficient of kinetic friction; apply Newton's first and second laws to analyzing the block.
block_dragging_2.content: Gravity, normal force, and applied force, and kinetic friction act on a block being dragged; by understanding these forces a physicist can understand the motion of the block.

friction_2.title: Friction 2
friction_2.objective: Recognize qualitative differences between static and kinetic friction; Explain that the magnitude of friction is independent of surface area.
friction_2.content: The magnitude of friction is independent of surface area of the object being dragged; maximum static friction is stronger than kinetic friction.

elevators_1.title: Elevators 1
elevators_1.subtitle: Drawing a Free-Body Diagram Given Acceleration of an Elevator
elevators_1.objective: Given a person in an elevator with a particular mass and acceleration, draw a correct free-body diagram of that person.
elevators_1.content: Inside an elevator, gravity and normal force act on the rider; normal force is a constraint force that adjusts to match a particular acceleration

block_dragging_3.title: Block Dragging 3
block_dragging_3.subtitle: Dragging a Non-Moving Box
block_dragging_3.objective: Given a block experiencing an applied force on a floor with both static and kinetic friction, draw a correct free-body diagram of the block, determine the motion of the block, and defend your answers using principles of friction.
block_dragging_3.content: If a block is not moving, a physicist determines if it will move by comparing applied force to maximum static friction; static friction is a constraint force.

vertical_friction.title: Vertical Friction
vertical_friction.objective: Draw a free-body diagram including friction as it acts on an object pressed against a wall or pole.
vertical_friction.content: Friction can be analyzed in several situations other than simply a block being dragged on a horizontal surface.

elevators_2.title: Elevators 2
elevators_2.subtitle: Drawing a Free-Body Diagram Given Motion of An Elevator
