elevators_2.objective: Given the description of motion of an elevator that is NOT moving at a constant velocity, draw a correct free-body diagram of a person in that elevator, defend that free-body diagram, and use it to describe what the person will feel.
elevators_2.content: Normal force changes in an elevator, leading to counterintuitive feelings; a physicist can make sense of these feelings by analyzing the forces and acceleration of a person in an elevator.

block_dragging_4.title: Block Dragging 4
block_dragging_4.subtitle: An Applied Force-Time Graph of a Block
block_dragging_4.objective: Given a force-time graph of a block on a surface, draw free-body diagrams for the block at different times and defend them; quantitatively analyze the surface based on the block.

friction_algebra.title: Friction Algebra
friction_algebra.subtitle: Symbolically Solving Friction Problems
friction_algebra.objective: Given a block being dragged on a surface, draw an algebraic free-body diagram on the block, reflect the motion of the block using algebraic conditions.

elevators_3.title: Elevator Problems 3
elevators_3.subtitle: Qualitative Kinematic Graphs and Free-Body Diagrams of an Elevator
elevators_3.objective: Draw kinematic graphs representing a person moving in a hypothetical elevator, draw free-body diagrams representing the forces on that person at a particular time, defend the free-body diagrams, and describe what the person will feel using the free-body diagram.

artificial_gravity.title: Artificial Gravity
artificial_gravity.objective: Apply our knowledge of forces in elevators to determine appropriate speeds of a rocket and the use of the 'vomit comet' to practice weightlessness.

vomit_comet.title: The Vomit Comet
vomit_comet.objective: Apply knowledge of forces in elevators to develop a quantitative model of the dynamics and kinematics of astronauts in NASA's weightlessness training plane (colloquially known as the vomit comet)

chinese_pole.title: The Chinese Pole
chinese_pole.objective: Use knowledge of static and kinetic friction to create a quantitative model of tricks done on the Chinese Pole by a circus performer.

vector_force_analysis.title: Vector Force Analysis (Newton's First Law)
vector_force_analysis.essential_questions: When, how, and why do items move?

inertia_newtons_first_law.title: Inertia and Newton's First Law
inertia_newtons_first_law.objective: Define inertia and relate inertia to mass
inertia_newtons_first_law.content: Inertia is a measure of resistance to change in motion; all matter has inertia; mass is a measure of inertia

newtons_model_1.title: Newton's Model 1
newtons_model_1.objective: Identify when net force is zero and when it is not; determine whether an abstract object accelerates, decelerates of moves at a constant speed based on its free-body diagrams
newtons_model_1.content: When an object is not moving or moving at a constant velocity, the net force acting on that object is zero; when an object is accelerating, the net force is not zero; accelerating in physics can mean speeding up, slowing down, or changing direction; when the net force on an object is zero we say it is 'in equilibrium'

basic_air_resistance.title: Basic Air Resistance
basic_air_resistance.objective: Explain what factors determine how crucial air resistance is in analyzing a situation.
basic_air_resistance.content: Air resistance is a crucial factor in a problem when an object moves very fast, has high surface area, has very low inertia, or when an extremely precise measurement is necessary.

newtons_model_2.title: Newton's Model 2
newtons_model_2.objective: Connect motion to free-body diagrams in abstract cases; for a given motion draw and defend a free-body diagrams; for a given free-body diagram determine and defend the motion of that object
newtons_model_2.content: When net force acts in the same direction as velocity, an object speeds up; when net force acts in the opposite direction as velocity, an object slows down; when net force is zero, an object is either not moving or moving at a constant velocity

inertia_stories.title: Inertia Stories
inertia_stories.objective: Explain real-life situations in which a change in inertia causes a change in experience; differentiate between inertial and gravitational mass.
inertia_stories.content: When objects have a high inertia, it is more difficult to change their speed or direction.

newtons_model_3.title: Newton's Model 3
newtons_model_3.subtitle: Abstract Application of Newton's Laws
newtons_model_3.objective: Connect motion to free-body diagrams in abstract cases; for a given motion draw and defend a free-body diagram; for a given fee-body diagram determine and defend the motion on that object.
newtons_model_3.notes: Includes two-step motion; in particular, focuses on objects that are already moving at a constant velocity when a change in force causes a change in motion; focuses primarily on abstract examples.
newtons_model_3.content: Physicists must understand how to use Newton's Laws to analyze motion abstractly

space_motion_1.title: Space Motion 1
space_motion_1.objective: Describe how objects move in space, contrast this motion with how objects move on earth, and give intuitive explanations for the difference.
space_motion_1.content: In space, gravity does not always act downwards, air resistance does not exist, and friction rarely exists. Thus, objects appear to move very differently than they do on earth while still following the same laws of physics.

forces_on_you.title: Forces on You
forces_on_you.objective: Using Newton's Three laws and free-body diagrams, describe forces acting on you in various situations and relate them to your experience.
forces_on_you.content: Newton's Laws can be used to analyze forces and motion acting on a person.
examples: Use Newton's Laws to describe the experience of your car pressing into your back when a car accelerates.
Use Newton's Laws to explain how a person walks.
forces_on_you.limits: Will not include very difficult elevator problems.

newtons_model_4A.title: Newton's Model 4A
newtons_model_4A.objective: Draw and defend free-body diagrams of situations that are particularly counterintuitive, those in which no force or a negative force exists in the direction of motion: kicking a box and shooting an arrow.
newtons_model_4A.content: At times, an object can move when the a net force is not acting in the direction the object is moving, counter to human intuition, but a careful connection between motion and Newton's Laws can create a logically sound model explaining how this motion occurs.

newtons_model_4B.title: Newton's Model 4B
newtons_model_4B.objective: Draw and defend free-body diagrams of situations that are particularly counterintuitive, those in which no force or a negative force exists in the direction of motion: lifting a weight and throwing a ball upward.
newtons_model_4B.content: At times, an object can move when the a net force is not acting in the direction the object is moving, counter to human intuition, but a careful connection between motion and Newton's Laws can create a logically sound model explaining how this motion occurs.

space_motion_2.title: Space Motion 2
space_motion_2.objective: Describe how objects move in space, contrast with how their move on earth, and explain this contrast using Newton's Laws and knowledge of forces.
space_motion_2.content: While motion in space appears very different than motion on earth due to the absence of omnipresent forces, motion in space follows the same laws of motion as motion on earth.

examine_newtons_laws_mathematically.title: Examine Newton's Laws Mathematically
examine_newtons_laws_mathematically.objective: Look at each of Newton's Laws as mathematical rules and derive mathematical results from each law.
examine_newtons_laws_mathematically.content: Newton's Laws are mathematical laws and physicists can make statements and prove them using Newton's Laws.

terminal_velocity_free_fall_survivors.title: Terminal Velocity and Free-Fall Survivors
terminal_velocity_free_fall_survivors.objective: Using Newton's First and Second Laws, describe why falling objects reach terminal velocity and discuss what factors determine terminal velocity; describe how it is possible to fall several miles through the air and live.
terminal_velocity_free_fall_survivors.content: If a person falls for a long time, air resistance acting on that person increases until a net force of zero acts on that person; after this point falling from higher heights does not increase the impact velocity.

space_motion_3.title: Space Motion 3
space_motion_3.objective: Defend the statement that all laws of motion are the same on earth, in space, and in all areas of the universe; and defend this notion using principles and examples.
space_motion_3.content: For most of Western history people thought that objects in space, the heavens, followed different laws of motion than objects on earth; early physicists proved mathematically that all objects in the universe follow the same laws of motion.

why_is_physics_hard.title: Why is Physics Hard?
why_is_physics_hard.objective: Using knowledge from both physics and psychology, describe why it is so difficult to figure out free-body diagrams of objects that are slowing down or moving at a constant speed.
why_is_physics_hard.content: Human intuition says that objects move if and only if a force pushes them, but Newton's Laws of motion state that force is related not to motion but change in motion; students must shed their misconceptions in order to master physics.

cognitive_psychology_dynamics.title: Cognitive Psychology of Dynamics
cognitive_psychology_dynamics.objective: Research and analyze scientific studies of the misconceptions in the study of forces and dynamics.
cognitive_psychology_dynamics.content: Students come to physics with misconceptions about how and why objects move; physicists have studied these misconceptions and developed theories and methods to help students internalize correct models of motion.

what_is_system.title: What is a system?
what_is_system.content: A system is several parts combined to make a whole

internal_external_forces.title: Internal and External Forces
internal_external_forces.objective: Identify internal and external forces acting on a defined system.
internal_external_forces.content: In an internal force, one object within the system acts on another object within the system; in an external force, an object outside the system acts on some part of the system; only external forces affect the motion of the center of mass of a system.

center_of_mass_1.title: Center of Mass 1: Simple Calculations
center_of_mass_1.objective: Calculate center of mass of a series of spheres with integer values for position and mass.
center_of_mass_1.content: The center of mass of a system is calculated via weighted a weighted average of position and mass.

atwood_machines_1.title: Atwood Machines 1
atwood_machines_1.subtitle: Introduction
atwood_machines_1.objective: Find the numerical acceleration of a frictionless Atwood machine with two masses.
atwood_machines_1.content: An atwood machine consists of two weights hanging over a pulley; an Atwood machine is most easily understood as a system.

center_of_mass_2.title: Center of Mass 2: Inconvenient Calculations
center_of_mass_2.objective: Find the center of mass of a series of spheres with inconvenient masses and positions, such as planets and moons.
center_of_mass_2.content: Center of mass can be calculated for spheres very close together or far apart, such as the center of mass of the earth-moon system.

center_of_mass_3.title: Center of Mass 3: Approximations
center_of_mass_3.objective: Approximate the center of mass of a system with an irregular shape, such as a dog.
center_of_mass_3.content: Physicists frequently use approximations to gain a sense of how a particular system works; the center of mass of an object may be located outside of that object.

atwood_machines_2.title: Atwood Machines 2
atwood_machines_2.subtitle: Friction and Extra Mass
atwood_machines_2.objective: Create a free-body diagram and find the acceleration of an Atwood machine with three blocks and/or subject to friction.
atwood_machines_2.content: The same rules of dynamics can be used to analyze a more complex Atwood machine.

stacking_problems_1.title: Stacking Problems 1: Numeric Stacking Problems
stacking_problems_1.objective: Draw correct numerical free-body diagrams for two blocks stacked on top of each other; demonstrate that these blocks follow the rules of system dynamics
stacking_problems_1.content: Multiple boxes stacked on each other are subject to the forces of gravity and multiple normal forces.

reduce_system_point_mass.title: Reduce a System to a Point Mass
reduce_system_point_mass.objective: Apply the concept of center of mass in order to treat a rotating projectile as a point mass; analyze the earth-moon system as a point mass; state from memory Isaac Newton's Principle that a complex system can be treated as a point mass.
reduce_system_point_mass.content: Any system, no matter how complex, can be analyzed kinematically and dynamically as a single point located at the center of mass of that system

human_system.title: The Human System
human_system.objective: Consider the human body as a system and look at theoretical findings and applications of the analysis
human_system.content: The human is a system; the center of mass is located within the torso when standing straight up; the center of mass moves when a human twists and bends; the center of mass can be located outside the body
examples: finding the center of mass of a human
male and female center of mass
motion of center of mass in high jump
motion of center of mass in long jump

atwood_machines_3.title: Atwood Machines 3
atwood_machines_3.subtitle: Symbolic Solutions
atwood_machines_3.objective: Solve a frictionless and more complex Atwood machine algebraically.
atwood_machines_3.content: An Atwood machine can be solved algebraically in order to derive new formulas that show how it works.

system_collision_explosion.title: System Collision and Explosions
system_collision_explosion.objective: Demonstrate that, during a collision or explosion, the velocity of the center of mass of a system is unchanged
system_collision_explosion.content: During a collision and explosion, the total momentum of the system is a constant value, and thus the velocity of the center of mass is unchanged.
system_collision_explosion.thoughts: Consider moving this to the collisions and explosions unit

atwood_machine_4.title: Atwood Machine 4
atwood_machine_4.subtitle: Proportionality
atwood_machine_4.objective: Use proportionality to predict the functioning of an Atwood machine; use this knowledge to demonstrate Newton's Second Law
atwood_machine_4.content: The acceleration of an Atwood machine is inversely proportional to total mass when net force is constant and is directly proportional to net force when total mass is constant, in accordance with Newton's Second Law.

stacking_problems_2.title: Stacking Problems 2: Symbolic Stacking Problems
stacking_problems_2.objective: Create algebraic free-body diagrams for two blocks stacked upon each other
stacking_problems_2.content: If two boxes are stacked on each other, they can be considered as two separate systems of one system; each outlook will give the same results.

atwood_machine_proof.title: Atwood Machine Proof
atwood_machine_proof.objective: Prove, in the case of an Atwood machine, that a system can be analyzed only by external forces and not internal forces.
atwood_machine_proof.content: If an Atwood machine's forces are broken into internal and external forces, then it can be shown that only external forces determine the motion of the Atwood machine and hte internal forces cancel out.

stacking_problems_3.title: Stacking Problems 3: Three Blocks
stacking_problems_3.objective: Create algebraic free-body diagrams for three blocks stacked upon each other.
stacking_problems_3.content: When multiple blocks are stacked on each other, each collection of adjacent boxes can be considered an indepedent system.

vector_form_conversion.title: Vector Form Conversion
vector_form_conversion.objective: Convert a vector between standard form and component form and back
vector_form_conversion.content: Vectors can be written as components or as a magnitude and direction; the rules of trigonometry can be used to convert between the different representations.

vector_component_addition.title: Vector Component Addition
vector_component_addition.objective: Add vectors and subtract vectors in multiple dimensions using component form.
vector_component_addition.content: Multi-dimensional vectors are easy to add and subtract in component form.

dragging_at_angle_1.title: Dragging at an Angle 1: Kinetic Friction Only
dragging_at_angle_1.objective: Analyze the motion of a block dragged at an angle with only kinetic friction; explain why the drag influences the normal force.
dragging_at_angle_1.content: An object being dragged and moving at an angle is subject to 4 forces: gravity, a normal force, an applied force and kinetic friction; a physicist can fully analyze the box use trigonometry combined with the dynamics of pulling a box at a horizontal angle.

hanging_sign_1.title: Hanging a Sign 1: Two Ropes
hanging_sign_1.objective: Draw a quantitative free-body diagram of a sign hanging from two ropes, both at an angle.
hanging_sign_1.content: A hanging and non-moving sign is subject to gravity and multiple applied forces; the applied forces can be broken into components in order to analyze the situation fully.

ramp_problems_1.title: Ramp Problems 1: No Friction
ramp_problems_1.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with either no friction or kinetic friction only.
ramp_problems_1.content: A block on a ramp is subject to gravity and normal force; physicists rotate the traditional cartesian coordinate system in order to properly analyze a the block; gravity must be broken into components to properly analyze a block on a ramp.

ramp_problems_2.title: Ramp Problems 2: Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_2.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with either no friction or kinetic friction only.
ramp_problems_2.content: In a ramp, kinetic friction adds another force in the negative-x direction.

dragging_at_angle_2.title: Dragging at an Angle 2: Static and Kinetic Friction
dragging_at_angle_2.objective: Analyze the motion of a block dragged at an angle under both static and kinetic friction.
dragging_at_angle_2.content: When static friction is added to a block pulled at an angle, a physicist must first determine if the block moves, then, if it does move, determine how fast it accelerates

hanging_sign_2.title: Hanging a Sign 2: Three Ropes
hanging_sign_2.objective: Draw a quantitative free-body diagram of a sign hanging from three ropes at angles.
hanging_sign_2.content: For an object hanging and not moving, adding more ropes to hang from adds more terms that must to each equation.

ramp_problems_3.title: Ramp Problems 3: Static and Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_3.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with both static and kinetic friction.
ramp_problems_3.content: When a block is on a ramp with both static and kinetic friction, a physicist must first determine if the block moves, and then, if it does, determine its acceleration.

ramp_problems_4.title: Ramp Problems 4: Algebraic with No Friction or Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_4.objective: Algebraically model a block on a ramp without friction or only kinetic friction; use proportionality to make predictions regarding the model
ramp_problems_4.content: Physicists can algebraically model a block on a ramp by repeating the same processes used to analyze the block numerically.

ramp_problems_x.title: Ramp Problems X
ramp_problems_x.subtitle: Ramp Conservation of Energy
ramp_problems_x.objective: Demonstrate that the conservation of energy is consistent with the laws of dynamics for an object on a ramp without friction and with friction.
ramp_problems_x.content: A block moving down a ramp is subject to the conservation of energy and the work-energy theorem, and this can be demonstrated numerically or algebraically.

dragging_at_angle_3.title: Dragging at an Angle 3: Algebraic Solutions
dragging_at_angle_3.objective: Algebraically model a block being dragged at an angle; create algebraic conditions for the block to experience different types of motion.
dragging_at_angle_3.content: Physicists can algebraically model a block dragged at an angle by repeating the same processes used to analyze the block numerically.

ramp_problems_5.title: Ramp Problems 5: Algebraic with Kinetic and Static Friction
ramp_problems_5.objective: Algebraically model a block on a ramp with both static and kinetic friction
ramp_problems_5.content: Physicists can algebraically model a block on a ramp by repeating the same processes used to analyze the block numerically.

pulling_a_cordon.title: Pulling a Cordon
pulling_a_cordon.objective: Create an algebraic model of a person pulling on a cordon rope.
pulling_a_cordon.content: A person pulling on a cordon rope creates two reaction forces from the rope pulling in each direction.

ramp_problems_6.title: Ramp Problems 6: Dragging and Object while on a ramp
ramp_problems_6.objective: Algebraically model a block being dragged on a ramp with friction.
ramp_problems_6.content: Adding an applied force to a block on a ramp adds an extra term in each equation.

2D_dynamics_level_6.title: 2-D Dynamics Level 6
2D_dynamics_level_6.objective: Create models using the principles of 2-dimensional dynamics.

circular_motion.title: Circular Motion
circular_motion.MUST ADD: I need to add the idea of properly defining centripetal force, especially in cases where the centripetal force is a combination of forces or a component of forces (for the circular motion trigonometry unit)

circular_vs_rotational_motion.title: Circular vs. Rotational Motion
circular_vs_rotational_motion.objective: Differentiate between examples of circular and rotational motion.
circular_vs_rotational_motion.content: When an object is in circular motion, its center of mass moves in a full circle around some center point; when an object is in rotational motion, the parts of the object rotate about some pivot point, and the center of mass does not necessarily move.

circular_motion_basics.title: Circular Motion Basics
circular_motion_basics.objective: Draw objects in circular motion; identify the centripetal force; predict what happens if the centripetal force is released
circular_motion_basics.content: When an object is in circular motion, its velocity is tangent to the circle and a force called the centripetal force pulls it towards the center of the circle.

circular_kinematics_1.title: Circular Kinematics 1
circular_kinematics_1.subtitle: Finding Speed
circular_kinematics_1.objective: Find the speed of an object in circular motion.
circular_kinematics_1.content: An object in circular motion travels a distance equal to the circumference of the circular in a time equal to the period of its motion.

vector_analysis_circular_motion_1.title: Vector Analysis of Circular Motion 1
vector_analysis_circular_motion_1.subtitle: Identify Vectors in Circular Motion
vector_analysis_circular_motion_1.objective: Identify the four relevant vectors for an object in circular motion: position, velocity, acceleration, and net force.
vector_analysis_circular_motion_1.content: When an object is moving in a circle and the origin is in the center of that circle, its position is radial and outward, its acceleration and force are radial and inward, and its velocity is tangential.

centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.title: Centripetal Acceleration and Force Formulas 1
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.objective: Use the centripetal acceleration formula alone.
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.content: The magnitude of the acceleration required to keep an object moving in a circle is equal to its speed squared divided by the radius of the circle; the magnitude of the force required to keep something moving in a circle is equal to the mass times the acceleration.

vector_analysis_circular_motion_2.title: Vector Analysis of Circular Motion 2
vector_analysis_circular_motion_2.subtitle: Apply Newton's Laws to Circular Motion
vector_analysis_circular_motion_2.objective: Explain why an object in circular motion is accelerating; explain why a net force must act on an object moving in a circle; extend Newton's Second Law to include turning
vector_analysis_circular_motion_2.content: Velocity is a vector, meaning any object changing direction is changing velocity; according to Newton's First Law any object changing velocity must have a net force acting on it; when an object experiences a net force perpendicular to its velocity, its direction of velocity changes.

centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.title: Centripetal Acceleration and Force Formula 2
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.objective: Given a radius and period of circular motion, determine necessary quantitative information about that motion.
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.content: Physicists can use multiple formulas together to learn crucial kinematic and dynamic quantities about an object moving in a circle.

vector_analysis_circular_motion_3.title: Newton's Model for Circular Motion 2
vector_analysis_circular_motion_3.subtitle: Counterintuitive Examples of Circular Motion
vector_analysis_circular_motion_3.objective: Using Newton's Model, explain why objects in a shopping bag do not fall out when it is flipped over and why the earth does not move towards the sun if it is attracted to it.
vector_analysis_circular_motion_3.content: When an object is moving in a circle, a force pulls it towards the center of that circle, but this force only causes it to change direction of velocity, not to move towards the center of the circle.

centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.title: Centripetal Acceleration and Force Formulas 3:
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.subtitle: Solving the Centripetal Acceleration Formula Algebraically
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.objective: Solve the centripetal acceleration formula for each item and demonstrate answers are correct using dimensional analysis.
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.content: Physicists can create new formulas by algebraically manipulating the formulas for centripetal force and acceleration.

finding_mass_of_sun.title: Finding Mass of Sun
finding_mass_of_sun.objective: Use the formulas for centripetal acceleration and gravitation to find the mass of the sun and earth.
finding_mass_of_sun.content: Because the earth moves in a nearly perfect circle around the sun, the centripetal force acting on the earth is equal to the gravitational force pulling it towards the sun; this knowledge can be used to discover the mass of the sun.
finding_mass_of_sun.notes: There is a related problem set on this topic.

centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.title: Centripetal Acceleration Formula 4
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.subtitle: Proportionality in the Centripetal Acceleration Formula
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.objective: Use proportionality to find numerical answers with not all information given and to explain real life experiences with turning a car.
centripetal_acceleration_force_formulas_.content: The magnitude of force required to keep a car moving in a circle is directly proportional to the square of the car's speed and inversely proportional to the radius of the circle the in which the car is moving.

vertical_circles_1.title: Vertical Circles 1
vertical_circles_1.subtitle: Constant Speed
vertical_circles_1.objective: Analyze the forces in a vertical circle when speed is constant, for example, the forces on a pilot as he loops over.
vertical_circles_1.content: When an object is swung around in a circle, gravity and tension combine to make the centripetal force acting on an object.

vertical_circles_2.title: Vertical Circles 2
vertical_circles_2.subtitle: Not Constant Speed
vertical_circles_2.objective: Analyze the forces in a vertical circle when speed is NOT constant; use circular motion to analyze a pendulum
vertical_circles_2.content: When an object is swung around in a circle, gravity and tension combine to make the centripetal force acting on an object; speed typically decreases when an object rises and increase when an object falls.

proving_centripetal_acceleration_formula.title: Proving the Centripetal Acceleration Formula
proving_centripetal_acceleration_formula.objective: Argue the formula for centripetal acceleration is numerically accurate using a conceptual geometry and limit-based argument.
proving_centripetal_acceleration_formula.content: The formula for centripetal acceleration can be demonstrated using geometry and an intuitive understanding of mathematical limits

vertical_circles_3.title: Vertical Circles 3
vertical_circles_3.subtitle: Algebraic Derivation
vertical_circles_3.objective: Derive a formula relating angular position, velocity, and acceleration for an object moving in a vertical circle.
vertical_circles_3.content: Physicists can analyze vertical circles algebraically as well as numerically.

gravitron.title: The Gravitron
gravitron.objective: Analyze the forces acting on a person in the gravitron amusement park ride; describe why a person feels 'pressed into' the wall during the ride.
gravitron.content: A person on a gravitron ride exhibits three forces: gravity, normal force, and static friction; normal force acts as centripetal force and its high magnitude increases the static friction and causes the person to stick to the wall.

hula_hoop.title: The Hula Hoop
hula_hoop.objective: Develop a quantitative model to examine the motion of a hula hoop.
hula_hoop.content: In a hula hoop, forces caused be a person's gyrations keep the hoop in circular motion and above the ground.

artificial_gravity_part_2.title: Artificial Gravity Part 2
artificial_gravity_part_2.objective: Develop a model of a space station in which people can walk around normally, as they would on earth, due to the dynamics of centripetal force.
artificial_gravity_part_2.content: A space station moving in a circle could potentially give humans an experience of standing or walking on the ground similar to that on planet earth.

circular_motion_trigonometry.title: Circular Motion Trigonometry
circular_motion_trigonometry.vision: Problems that require both circular motion and trigonometry: banking on a highway, using polar coordinates to describe motion

centripetal_force_components.title: Centripetal Force Component
centripetal_force_components.objective: Identify situations in which the centripetal force is a component of another force or a sum of various components; draw free-body diagrams of such situations.

circular_motion_components.title: Circular Motion Components
circular_motion_components.objective: With guidance, break down the free-body diagram of an object in circular motion; break forces into radial, tangential, and vertical components.

tire_swings.title: Tire Swings
tire_swings.objective: Analyze the motion of a mass hanging from a string and swinging in a horizontal circle.

banked_turns.title: Banked Turns
banked_turns.objective: Analyze the motion of a car driving on a bank (or a runner on a banked turn).

wizard_circles.title: Wizard Circles
wizard_circles.objective: Analyze the motion of an object moving in a vertical circle in a different plane than the object.

vertical_circle_functions.title: Vertical Circle Functions
vertical_circle_functions.objective: Create functions for the position, velocity, acceleration, and net force acting on an object moving in a vertical circle as a function of time.

lassos.title: Lassos
lassos.objective: Analyze a rope in circular motion in all different planes.

lasso_the_moon.title: Lasso The Moon
lasso_the_moon.objective: Create a model of a person literally trying to lasso the moon.

multiple_string_circular_motion.title: Multiple String Circular Motion
multiple_string_circular_motion.objective: Create a model of a ball, attached to multiple strings in different directions, moving in circular motion.

basic_gravity.title: Basic Gravity
basic_gravity.objective: Recognize examples of gravity on earth and in space; know gravity exists in space; define gravity as masses attracting rather than simply falling.
basic_gravity.content: Gravity is a force that attracts all masses to all other masses; gravity exists both on earth and in space.

basic_orbits.title: Basic Orbits
basic_orbits.objective: Recognize basic facts about orbits: they are elliptical etc. Recognize the orbits of objects such as planets and comets
basic_orbits.content: All planets and all other objects in orbit such as dwarf planets and comets move around the sun in an ellipse; some of these ellipses are very close to a circle.

mass_vs_weight_1.title: Mass vs. Weight 1
mass_vs_weight_1.objective: Differentiate between mass and weight, including how weight changes in different areas.
mass_vs_weight_1.content: Mass is the total amount of matter or inertia that an object has; weight is the strength of gravity pulling the object downward when it is on a planet.

universal_attraction.title: Universal Attraction
universal_attraction.objective: Memorize the definition of gravity as a universal attraction between masses; explain how people experience attraction to all masses, but little of it is felt.
universal_attraction.content: All masses are attracted by gravity, most of these attractions are too weak for you to feel.

astronomical_examples_gravitation.title: Astronomical Examples of Gravitation
astronomical_examples_gravitation.objective: Explain star formation, planet formation, and the existence of earth's atmosphere, and the absence of an atmosphere on other planets.
astronomical_examples_gravitation.content: Gravitational attraction of dust particles causes stars to form; earth's atmosphere exists due to gravitational attraction.

comet_orbits.title: Comet Orbits
comet_orbits.objective: Explain how energy changes between GPE and KE in a comet
comet_orbits.content: As a comet approaches earth, GPE converts to KE; as it moves away KE converts to GPE.

earth_is_round.title: The Earth is Round?
earth_is_round.objective: Examine counterintuitive consequences of the fact that the earth is round; explain Newton's revelation about the moon and the apple.
earth_is_round.content: Because the earth is round, the direction we called 'down' is actually 'inward'; an apple and the moon are both falling inward towards earth.

keplers_first_law.title: Kepler's First Law
keplers_first_law.subtitle: Ellipse Geometry
keplers_first_law.objective: State Kepler's First Law; Rigorously define an ellipse and relate this definition to orbits; compare orbits of different eccentricity.
keplers_first_law.notes: Must recognize that earth's orbit is nearly spherical and eccentricity is NOT responsible for the seasons.
keplers_first_law.content: An ellipse is formed by all points whose combined distance from two points is the same; the eccentricity of an ellipse represents how elongated it is; different object's orbits have different eccentricities; earth's orbit is nearly circular.

keplers_second_law.title: Kepler's Second Law
keplers_second_law.objective: State Kepler's second law, demonstrate it with diagrams, and relate it to changes in energy.
keplers_second_law.content: The area created by an object's orbit is equal for all unit times.

keplers_third_law.title: Kepler's Third Law
keplers_third_law.objective: State Kepler's Third law; solve quantitative problems involving Kepler's Third Law; determine correct altitude of a cell-phone satellite
keplers_third_law.content: The period of an orbit squared divided by the radius of an orbit cubed is constant for all objects orbitting a particular body; this can be used to place items in a place there they have a particular orbit.

significance_of_keplers_laws.title: Significance of Kepler's Laws
significance_of_keplers_laws.objective: Explain how Newton's proof of Kepler's Laws was crucial in shaping human understanding of the universe
significance_of_keplers_laws.content: By proving Kepler's Laws, Isaac Newton showed that objects in space followed the same principles as objects on earth.

gravitational_vs_inertial_mass.title: Gravitational vs. Inertial Mass
gravitational_vs_inertial_mass.objective: Differentiate between gravitational and inertial mass while recognizing their equality.
gravitational_vs_inertial_mass.content: The physics quantity of mass represents both inertia and the strength of gravitational attraction to that object.

jumping_through_center_of_earth.title: Jumping through the center of the earth. (A thought experiment)
jumping_through_center_of_earth.objective: Examine using rigorous terminology, free-body diagrams, and kinematic graphs what would happen if you jumped through the center of the earth
jumping_through_center_of_earth.notes: Must refer to Newton's Shell Principle
jumping_through_center_of_earth.content: If you were to jump through the center of the earth, you would come out the other side with no velocity; a physicist can prove this principle with the laws of dynamics and kinematics.

non_round_earth.title: A non-round Earth (A thought experiment)
non_round_earth.objective: Describe how life on earth might be different if the shape of earth were different but the force of gravity was still proportional to mass.
non_round_earth.content: Were earth any other shape, gravity would pull you towards the center of that shape.

non_round_earth_2.title: Non-Round Earth 2
non_round_earth_2.objective: Invent a different planet of a non-round shape and qualitatively and/or quantitatively describe life on this planet.
non_round_earth_2.content: A physicist can invent a hypothetical planet with a different shape and then imagine what might happen on that planet.

electrostatic_basics.title: Electrostatic Basics
electrostatic_basics.objective: Describe basic facts about electricity necessary to study electrostatics: parts of an atom; attraction and repulsion of subatomic particles
electrostatic_basics.content: Atoms are made of protons, neutrons, and electrons; two protons repel, two electrons repel, but a proton and an electron attract.

charging_by_friction_electrostatic_disch.title: Charging by friction and electrostatic discharge
charging_by_friction_electrostatic_disch.objective: Draw diagrams charging by friction and electrostatic discharge; recognize real-life examples of each.
charging_by_friction_electrostatic_disch.content: When two objects are rubbed together, electrons move between them in a process called charging by friction; when a charged object is placed near a conductor, electrons move to the conductor in a process called electrostatic discharge.

what_is_charge.title: What is charge?
what_is_charge.objective: Describe qualitatively and quantitatively what it means for an object to be charged; describe how an object gains a positive or a negative charge.
what_is_charge.content: Charged objects have different numbers of protons and electrons; charged objects exhibit electrostatic properties; only electrons move between atoms so an object can only gain a positive charge by losing electrons.

shocks_lightning.title: Shocks and lightning
shocks_lightning.objective: Draw diagrams and write narrative explaining how an electric shock, a bolt of lightning, and/or a gas station fire occurs
shocks_lightning.content: Shocks are created when an object first charges by friction, then exhibits electrostatic discharge.

electrostatics_vs_electric_current.title: Electrostatics vs. Electric Current
electrostatics_vs_electric_current.objective: Compare and contrast between static and current electricity; recognize examples of both
electrostatics_vs_electric_current.content: In static electricity, objects build and release charges; in current electricity electrons drift through neutral wires.

electrostatic_induction.title: Electrostatic Induction
electrostatic_induction.objective: Define electrostatic polarization as a type of charge; draw diagrams and write narrative to show how electric charge can be acquired without exchange of electrons; recall real world examples of electrostatic induction.
electrostatic_induction.content: When an object is polarized, one side is positive charged and the other side negatively charged; objects can become polarized without touching or exchanging electrons.

van_de_graaf_generator.title: The van de Graaf Generator
van_de_graaf_generator.objective: Draw diagrams and give narrative explaining how a van de Graaf Generator generates large shocks, causes hair to raise, and causes other effects.
van_de_graaf_generator.content: a van de Graaf generator works by generating a large charge with a belt moving across a comb, then either collecting the charge to create electrostatic effects or enabling a large discharge.

positives_or_negative_charge.title: Positive or negative charge?
positives_or_negative_charge.objective: Justify that the electrostatic phenomenon we observe would be identical if electrons moved the opposite way as we predict; describe how an electroscope is used and the value of the electroscope.
positives_or_negative_charge.notes: In particular, describe how a van de Graaf generator works opposite of how it is often described.
positives_or_negative_charge.content: Physicists are unable to determine from most observable electrostatic phenomena whether a charge is positive or negative.

which_has_more_force_1.title: Which has more force? 1: Basic Examples
which_has_more_force_1.objective: For two masses or charges, identify the force involved, whether they attract or repel, and which pair experiences more force.
which_has_more_force_1.content: Objects with more mass and less distance between them experience greater gravitational force; objects with more charge and less distance between them experience a greater electrostatic force.

fields_1.title: Fields 1: Fields of One Object
fields_1.objective: Draw electric or gravitational fields of a single object.
fields_1.content: Electric field illustrates the force that would act on a positive charge; gravitational field illustrates the force that would act on a mass; electric field points towards a negative charge and away from a positive charge.

which_has_more_force_2.title: Which has more force? 2: Written Examples
which_has_more_force_2.objective: For written descriptions of pairs of masses or charges, identify which pairs experience more force and why.
which_has_more_force_2.content: The amount of gravitational or electrostatic force can be determined from written descriptions.

fields_2.title: Fields 2: Fields of two Objects
fields_2.objective: Draw electric or gravitational fields of two charged or massive objects.
fields_2.content: When two charged or massive objects are together, electric and gravitational fields bend to indicate the summation of forces caused by the two objects.

law_of_gravitation_1.title: Law of Gravitation 1
law_of_gravitation_1.subtitle: Two objects
law_of_gravitation_1.objective: Numerically solve Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation.
law_of_gravitation_1.content: The magnitude of gravity acting on two objects is proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers of mass; the constant of proportionality is called the Universal Gravitational Constant.

coulombs_law_1.title: Coulombs Law 1
coulombs_law_1.subtitle: Two charges
coulombs_law_1.content: The magnitude of the electrostatic force acting on two objects is proportional to their charges and inversely proportional to the square of the sitance between their centers of charge; the constant of proportionality is called the Coulomb's Law Constant.

law_of_gravitation_2.title: Law of Gravitation 2
law_of_gravitation_2.objective: Solve Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation and relate the result to Newton's Third Law.
law_of_gravitation_2.content: Whenever there are two masses A and B, A exerts a force of gravity on B and B exerts a force of gravity on A with equal magnitude and opposite direction; the force is always attractive and the magnitude is given by Newton's Universal Law of Gravitation

coulombs_law_2.title: Coulombs Law 2
coulombs_law_2.objective: Solve Coulomb's Law and connect it to Newton's Third Law.
coulombs_law_2.content: Whenever there are two charged objects, A exerts an electrostatic force on B and B exerts an electrostatic force on A with equal magnitude and opposite direction; the force is attractive if the charges are opposite and repulsive if the charges are like; the magnitude of the force is given by Coulomb's Law.

law_of_gravitation_3.title: Law of Gravitation 3
law_of_gravitation_3.subtitle: Gravitation on a Planet
law_of_gravitation_3.objective: Numerically solve Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation on a planet; derive free-fall acceleration numerically.
law_of_gravitation_3.content: When a person is on a planet, they attract the planet and the planet attracts them with a force of equal magnitude and opposite direction; the distance between the center of mass of the person and the center of mass and the planet is effectively equal to the radius of the planet.

coulombs_law_3.title: Coulombs Law 3
coulombs_law_3.subtitle: Coulombs Law Inside Atoms
coulombs_law_3.objective: Use Coulombs Law inside of atoms; use the electronic charge and unit of Angstroms to determine relevant quantities inside the atom
coulombs_law_3.content: Coulomb's Law can be applied to determine the attraction between electrons and nuclei within an atom.

fields_3.title: Fields 3: Fields of Multiple Objects
fields_3.objective: Draw gravitational or electric fields for several objects.
fields_3.content: When more than two charged or massive objects are near each other, they create derivable patterns of electric and magnetic fields.

derive_free_fall_acceleration.title: Derive Free-Fall Acceleration
derive_free_fall_acceleration.objective: Derive, defend, and apply the formula for free-fall acceleration on a planet.
derive_free_fall_acceleration.content: The free-fall acceleration on a planet depends only upon the properties of the planet and no properties of the object in free-fall; physicists can derive this formula from Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation.

algebraic_inverse_square.title: Algebraic Inverse Square
algebraic_inverse_square.objective: Solve inverse square laws algebraically; determine the dimensions of the gravitational and electric constants
algebraic_inverse_square.content: Inverse square laws can be algebraically manipulated to determine new formulas; the constants of the inverse square laws have units that have no physical meaning but connect the units of the principles.

inverse_square_law_proportionality.title: Inverse Square Law Proportionality
inverse_square_law_proportionality.objective: Given a certain attraction or repulsion between certain masses or charges, determine what a new reaction or repulsion would be between slightly changed values.
inverse_square_law_proportionality.content: Proportionality can be used to relate gravitational and electrostatic force to other quantities, even if not all information is known.

why_inverse_square.title: Why inverse square?
why_inverse_square.objective: Use field diagrams and spherical geometry to explain why inverse square laws are inverse square laws.
why_inverse_square.content: Gravitational and electrostatic force are inversely proportional to distance squared because the gravitational and electric field spread out into three-dimensional space.

force_behind_chemistry.title: The Force Behind Chemistry
force_behind_chemistry.objective: Demonstrate why electrostatic, not gravitational force, determines how atoms and subatomic particles behave.
force_behind_chemistry.content: On subatomic scales, the gravitational force is many orders of magnitude less than the electrostatic force. As a result, only the electrostatic force is used to describe how atoms behave.

different_dimensional_universe.title: Different Dimensional Universe
different_dimensional_universe.objective: Consider how the inverse square laws would be different if we lived in a universe with other than three dimensions.
different_dimensional_universe.content: Gravitational and electrostatic forces follow inverse square laws because we live in a three-dimensional universe. If we lived in a universe of different dimensionality, the gravitational and electrostatic forces would follow different proportionality laws.

quantitative_orbits.title: Quantitative Orbits
quantitative_orbits.vision: Will contain information on conic sections, different types of orbits, quantitative analyses of Kepler's Laws, historical information on the importance of keplers laws and orbits in the development of science, and energy in orbits; For the AP curriculum, the universal gravitational potentail energy formual will be here

simple_magnets.title: Simple Magnets
simple_magnets.objective: Recognize North and South poles of a magnet, predict attraction and repulsion in a magnet, recognize earth's magnetic field, explain how a compass works
simple_magnets.notes: north and south poles, earth's magnetic field, how a compass works.

simple_electromagnet.title: Simple Electromagnet
simple_electromagnet.objective: Explain how to build a simple electromagnet.

simple_magnetic_fields.title: Simple Magnetic Fields
simple_magnetic_fields.objective: Draw a magnetic field of a single bar magnet and of the earth.

how_do_magnets_work.title: How do magnets work?
how_do_magnets_work.objective: Explain and diagram how a magnet works.

electron_motion_in_magnetic_field.title: Electron motion in a magnetic field
electron_motion_in_magnetic_field.objective: Determine, using right-hand rules, how an electron moves within a magnetic field; recognize why a bar magnet lines up in an electric field.

magnetization_of_metal.title: Magnetization of metal
magnetization_of_metal.objective: Explain what happens on a subatomic level when a piece of metal is magnetized

earths_magnetic_field.title: Earth's Magnetic Field
earths_magnetic_field.objective: Explain why the earth has a magnetic field and identify crucial consequences of the earth's magnetic field.

dc_motors_electrical_generators.title: DC Motors and Electrical Generators
dc_motors_electrical_generators.objective: Using concepts of magnetic fields and electric current, explain how a DC motor and an electrical generator works.

multiple_magnetic_fields.title: Multiple Magnetic Fields
multiple_magnetic_fields.objective: Draw the magnetic field of two magnets and explain why they would attract or repel.

what_is_light.title: What is light?
what_is_light.objective: Narrate qualitatively why light exists using Faraday's Law, Ampere's Law, and other electromagnetic laws.

momentum_formula.title: The Momentum Formula
momentum_formula.objective: Use the momentum formula to solve numerical problems.

memorize_conservation_of_momentum.title: Memorize the Conservation of Momentum
memorize_conservation_of_momentum.objective: Memorize, word for word, the conservation of momentum.
memorize_conservation_of_momentum.content: During any process, the total momentum before the process equals the total momentum after the process.

conservation_of_momentum_1.title: Conservation of Momentum 1
conservation_of_momentum_1.subtitle: Two Cars
conservation_of_momentum_1.objective: Use the conservation of momentum to solve simple collision problems with the aid of a table.
conservation_of_momentum_1.content: When two cars collide, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision; this information can be used to find useful information about the cars

conservation_of_momentum_2.title: Conservation of Momentum 2
conservation_of_momentum_2.subtitle: Perfectly Inelastic Collisions
conservation_of_momentum_2.objective: Use the conservation of momentum to analyze crashes in which two objects stick together.
conservation_of_momentum_2.content: When two cars crash and stick together, it is called a perfectly inelastic collision; a perfectly inelastic collision can also be analyzed using the principles of conservation of momentum.

conservation_of_momentum_3.title: Conservation of Momentum 3
conservation_of_momentum_3.subtitle: Head-On Collisions
conservation_of_momentum_3.objective: Use the conservation of momentum and guiding tables to solve problems involving cars moving in different directions.
conservation_of_momentum_3.content: When two cars are moving in different directions, physicists represent direction with the sign of the velocity.

conservation_of_momentum_4.title: Conservation of Momentum 4
conservation_of_momentum_4.subtitle: Explosions
conservation_of_momentum_4.objective: Use the conservation of momentum and guiding tables to analyze explosions.
conservation_of_momentum_4.content: The total momentum before an explosion equals the total momentum after the explosion.

collision_formula_derivation.title: Collision Formula Derivation
collision_formula_derivation.objective: Represent each situation involving conservation of momentum with an algebraic formula and explain what each term of that formula represents.
collision_formula_derivation.content: Physicists use the conservation of momentum to create a formula specific to individual situations.

conservation_of_momentum_5.title: Conservation of Momentum 5
conservation_of_momentum_5.objective: Use an algebraic formula to solve problems involving the conservation of momentum with information and method is not clearly given.
conservation_of_momentum_5.content: Physicists invent and solve formulas using the conservation of momentum to find useful information regarding a collision.

collision_energy.title: Collision Energy
collision_energy.objective: Given a collision or explosion, analyze the collision quantitatively, determine if kinetic energy is lost, gained, or conserved; analyze the source of work done on a system.
collision_energy.content: While momentum is always conserved in a collision or explosion, energy can be gained or lost depending upon the individual situation.

conservation_of_momentum_6.title: Conservation of Momentum 6
conservation_of_momentum_6.subtitle: Symbolic Analysis
conservation_of_momentum_6.objective: Solve for an algebraic solution to collision and explosion problems; prove solutions are dimensionally correct; use proportionality to analyze solutions
conservation_of_momentum_6.content: Physicists will often derive formulas based on the conservation of momentum, solve them algebraically, and theorize regarding relevant proportionality relationships.

elastic_collisions.title: Elastic Collisions
elastic_collisions.objective: Define elastic and inelastic collisions; recognize common elastic and inelastic collisions; numerically analyze objects undergoing an elastic collision
elastic_collisions.content: In an elastic collision, the kinetic energy before the collision equals the kinetic energy after the collision; this principle gives physicists another formula from which to find information regarding the collision.

advanced_pool_ball_collision.title: Advanced Pool Ball Collision
advanced_pool_ball_collision.objective: Derive formulas that explain pool ball collisions and use relate these formulas to the actual reality in a pool ball collision.
advanced_pool_ball_collision.content: When two objects collide elastically, physicists can derive new formulas to simplify the problem; two pool balls show a simple elastic collision physicists can use to better understand elastic collisions.

newtons_cradle.title: Newton's Cradle
newtons_cradle.objective: Use the conservation of momentum in an elastic collision to explain how a Newton's Cradle works.
newtons_cradle.content: A combination of the conservation of momentum and the conservation of kinetic energy causes the effect people see in a Newton's Cradle

totally_inelastic_collision_energy_loss.title: Totally Inelastic Collision Energy Loss
totally_inelastic_collision_energy_loss.objective: Determine a formula for kinetic energy lost in the case of a totally inelastic collision; apply this formula to several possible situations
totally_inelastic_collision_energy_loss.content: When two objects stick together following a collision, kinetic energy is lost; the total amount of energy lost can be algebraically derived and analyzed by a physicist.

tennis_ball_basketball.title: The Tennis Ball and the Basketball
tennis_ball_basketball.objective: Create an algebraic model for the motion of a tennis ball dropped on top of basketball (resulting in an elastic collision between then)
tennis_ball_basketball.content: A tennis ball dropped on top of a basketball will end up rising very high into the air; physicists can algebraically derive how high the tennis ball will rise from available formulas.

impulse_formula_1.title: Impulse Formula 1
impulse_formula_1.objective: Solve straightforward numerical problems using the impulse formula.
impulse_formula_1.content: Impulse is equal to net force multiplied by time elapsed and is also equal to change in momentum.

impulse_concepts.title: Impulse Concepts
impulse_concepts.objective: Answer real-world written questions by referring to the impulse formula; describe what the term 'breaking a fall' means.
impulse_concepts.content: The impulse formula implies that speeding up or slowing down in a greater time would mean you need a lesser force; padded surfaces allow the same impulse with lower force.

dynamic_graphs_1.title: Dynamic Graphs 1
dynamic_graphs_1.subtitle: Introducing Dynamic Graphs
dynamic_graphs_1.objective: Qualitatively relate simple (1-2 step) momentum-time and net force-time graphs; answer quantitative questions on momentum graphs
dynamic_graphs_1.content: The relationship between a momentum-time graph and a net force-time graph is the same as that between a position-time graph and a velocity-time graph.

impulse_formula_3.title: Impulse Formula 3
impulse_formula_3.subtitle: Algebraic Proof
impulse_formula_3.objective: Prove the impulse formula is equivalent to Newton's Second Law.
impulse_formula_3.content: The impulse formula is mathematically equivalent to Newton's Second Law

dynamic_graphs_2.title: Dynamic Graphs 2
dynamic_graphs_2.objective: Quantitatively relate momentum-time graphs to net-force-time graphs.
dynamic_graphs_2.content: The slope of a momentum time graph at a given time is equal to the net force at that time; the area under the curve of a net force-time graph is equal to the change in momentum over that time period.

dynamic_graphs_3.title: Dynamic Graphs 3
dynamic_graphs_3.objective: Quantitatively relate all five kinematic and dynamic graphs: position-time, velocity-time, acceleration-time, momentum-time, and net-force time.
dynamic_graphs_3.content: Multiplying the y-axis of a velocity-time graph by the mass yields a momentum-time graph; multiplying the y-axis of an acceleration-time graph by the mass yields a net force-time graph.

kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 1
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.objective: Relate the five 'time' graphs of kinematic and dynamic quantities: position, velocity, acceleration, momentum, force.
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.content: All of the five kinematic and dynamic graphs are related by mathematical operations and physical formulas.
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.note: I still need to determine what exactly makes kinematic and dynamic graphs 1, 2, and 3 different

impulse_formula_4.title: Impulse Formula 4
impulse_formula_4.subtitle: Proportionality and Inferences
impulse_formula_4.objective: Analyze impulse by using proportionality; make real world inferences using this analysis.
impulse_formula_4.content: For objects with the same change in momentum, net force and time elapsed are inversely proportional.

kinematic_dynamics_graphs_2.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 2
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_2.objective: Quantitatively relate the five graphs of kinematic and dynamic values.
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_2.content: All of the five kinematic and dynamic graphs are related by mathematical operations and physical formulas.

kinematic_dynamic_graphs_3.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 3
kinematic_dynamic_graphs_3.objective: Create quantitative kinematic and dynamic graphs based on a complex real world description.
kinematic_dynamic_graphs_3.content: All of the five kinematic and dynamic graphs are related by mathematical operations and physical formulas.

period_and_frequency_1.title: Period and Frequency 1
period_and_frequency_1.objective: Define and calculate period and frequency.
period_and_frequency_1.content: The period of motion is the time for a single cycles; the frequency of motion is the number of cycles per time.

harmonic_v_linear_motion.title: Harmonic vs. Linear Motion
harmonic_v_linear_motion.objective: Define and give examples of harmonic and linear motion.
harmonic_v_linear_motion.content: Linear motion consists of motion that occurs once; harmonic motion is motion that occurs in a repeating pattern.

period_frequency_2.title: Period and Frequency 2
period_frequency_2.objective: Correctly use the formula T = 1 /f, including with proportionality
period_frequency_2.content: Period and frequency are mathematically reciprocal; period and frequency are always inversely proportional.

position_time_graphs_periodic_motion.title: Position-Time Graphs of Periodic Motion
position_time_graphs_periodic_motion.objective: Draw simple position-time graphs of periodic motion.
position_time_graphs_periodic_motion.content: The position-time graphs for periodic motion are will appear as wave pattern (a trigonometric function).

periodic_frequency_3.title: Period and Frequency 3: Specific Formulas
periodic_frequency_3.objective: Numerically solve the formulas for period and frequency of a spring or pendulum.
periodic_frequency_3.content: The period of a pendulum is equal to 2pi times the square root of the length divided by free fall acceleration; the period of a block-spring system is equal to 2pi times the square root of the mass of a block divided by the spring constant.

periodic_position_function.title: Periodic Position Function
periodic_position_function.objective: Use a trigonometric function to represent the position of an object in harmonic motion, with period and amplitude correct but phase not considered.
periodic_position_function.content: Physicists represent the position-time function of an object in harmonic motion by a trigonometric function.
periodic_position_function.note: Velocity and acceleration of an object in periodic motion will be analyzed using calculus in the unit on differential equations of simple harmonic motion

period_frequency_4.title: Period and Frequency 4: Symbolic Solutions Algebra
period_frequency_4.objective: Algebraically solve the period and frequency formulas for springs and pendulums
period_frequency_4.content: Physicists can solve the formula for period and frequency of a harmonic system algebraically in order to invent new formulas

period_frequency_5.title: Period and Frequency 5: Proportionality
period_frequency_5.objective: Use proportionality to analyze the formulas for frequency and period of a pendulum.
period_frequency_5.content: The period of a pendulum is proportional to the square root of the length of the pendulum; the period of a mass-spring system is proportional to the square root of the mass

periodic_position_function_2.title: Periodic Position Function 2
periodic_position_function_2.objective: Use trigonometric formulas to represent the position of an object in harmonic motion, including correct amplitude, period, and phase.
periodic_position_function_2.content: The phase of a trigonometric function indicates where that function begins; a pendulum or spring that is pulled back begins with a different phase than one which is struck.

spring_pendulum_energy_1.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 1
spring_pendulum_energy_1.objective: In diagrams or sentences, explain qualitatively how energy changes in a spring or pendulum; explain the 'pendulum nose' phenomnenon

hookes_law.title: Hooke's Law
hookes_law.objective: Use Hooke's Law to predict forces acting on a spring, and analyze Hooke's Law with proportionality.

newtons_model_pendulums.title: Newton's Model for Pendulums
newtons_model_pendulums.objective: Draw free-body diagrams of a pendulum at different points in its motion and relate these free-body didagrms tot he motion of the pendulum using Newton's Model.

newtons_model_springs.title: Newton's Model for Springs
newtons_model_springs.objective: Draw free-body diagrams of a pendulum at different points in its motion and relate these free-body didagrms tot he motion of the pendulum using Newton's Model.

spring_pendulum_energy_2.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 2: Energy Equations for Springs and Pendulums
spring_pendulum_energy_2.objective: Create equations of motion for springs and pendulums using the conservation of energy; explain the terms of these equations; defend these equations using dimensional analysis.

spring_pendulum_energy_3.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 3: Quantitative Energy Problems for Springs and Pendulums
spring_pendulum_energy_3.notes: Create and solve equations of motion for springs and pendulums using the conservation of energy.

spring_pendulum_energy_4.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 4: Energy Algebra for a Spring
spring_pendulum_energy_4.objective: Create an algebraically solve equations of motion for a spring from the conservation of energy; derive equations that relate amplitude and max-speed

spring_pendulum_energy_5.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 5: Energy Algebra for a Pendulum
spring_pendulum_energy_5.objective: Create an algebraically solve equations of motion for a pendulum from the conservation of energy; derive equations that relate amplitude and max-speed

periodic_kinematic_functions_1.title: Periodic Kinematic Functions 1
periodic_kinematic_functions_1.objective: Using the periodic functions for position from the previous unit and the energy equations from level 3, derive velocity-time and acceleration-time kinematic equations for harmonic motion.
periodic_kinematic_functions_1.limits: Functions developed need not include phase or damping.

vertical_springs.title: Vertical Springs
vertical_springs.objective: Prove that a vertical spring works identically to a horizontal spring.

damping.title: Damping
damping.objective: Examine the effect of damping on the position-time graph of springs and pendulums.

periodic_kinematic_functions_2.title: Periodic Kinematic Functions 2
periodic_kinematic_functions_2.objective: Without using calculus, create position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs for simple harmonic motion in terms of amplitude and phase.
periodic_kinematic_functions_2.limits: Does not include damping or differential equations.

differential_equations_periodic_motion.title: Differential Equations for Periodic Motion
differential_equations_periodic_motion.notes: Solving differential equations for simple harmonic motion and analyzing the result.

rotational_kinematics.title: Rotational Kinematics
rotational_kinematics.notes: I need to add content on kinematic graphs...but this unit seems full with all this computational stuff

rotational_position_displacement.title: Rotational Position and Displacement
rotational_position_displacement.objective: Determine rotational position and displacement in radians for simple examples; define a radian; know a radian is dimensionless

rotational_velocity_calculations.title: Rotational Velocity Calculations
rotational_velocity_calculations.objective: Calculate rotational velocity in radians per second

rotational_velocity_conversions.title: Rotational Velocity Conversions
rotational_velocity_conversions.objective: Use conversion factors to convert rotational velocity from non-SI units to radians per second.

rotational_linear_velocity.title: Rotational and Linear Velocity
rotational_linear_velocity.objective: Explain the difference between rotational and linear velocity and relate them numerically

angular_velocity_of_real_things.title: Angular Velocity of Real Things
angular_velocity_of_real_things.objective: Determine the angular velocity in radians per second of the hands of a clock, a rotating planet, a revolving planet

rotational_kinematic_equations_1.title: Rotational Kinematic Equations 1
rotational_kinematic_equations_1.objective: Solve kinematic equations for rotational motion with quantities given.

rotational_kinematic_equations_2.title: Rotational Kinematic Equations 2
rotational_kinematic_equations_2.objective: Relate the kinematic quantities and equations for linear and rotational motion
rotational_kinematic_equations_2.note: This pod was once flagged as redundant, but when editing I couldn't see why

angular_linear_velocity_on_planet.title: Angular and Linear Velocity on a Planet
angular_linear_velocity_on_planet.objective: Determine the linear velocity of a person located at a particular latitude on a planet.

rotational_kinematic_equations_3.title: Rotational Kinematic Equations 3
rotational_kinematic_equations_3.objective: When rotational kinematic quantities are given in inconvenient ways (such as rpm, or time per rotation, or linear motion is given), determine the rotational quantities in correct units and then use the rotational kinematic equations.

rotational_vs_linear_velocity.title: Rotational vs. Linear Velocity
rotational_vs_linear_velocity.objective: Compare the rotational and linear velocity of items in different locations on a rotating disc; answer conceptual questions related to rotational and linear velocity

direction_rotational_kinematics_quantiti.title: Direction of Rotational Kinematics Quantities
direction_rotational_kinematics_quantiti.objective: Use right-hand rules to determine the directions of rotational kinematics quantities.

advanced_angular_acceleration.title: Advanced Angular Acceleration
advanced_angular_acceleration.objective: Determine the angular acceleration of a wheel as a car accelerates; determine angular acceleration if a planet were to speed up or slow down.

rotational_kinematics_advanced.title: Rotational Kinematics Advanced
rotational_kinematics_advanced.objective: Make inferences using algebraic and proportionality analysis regarding the rotational and linear speeds of a person located at different points on the earth

winter_is_coming.title: Winter is Coming?
winter_is_coming.objective: Design a hypothetical planet for which seasons have irregular lengths.

the_long_night.title: The Long Night
the_long_night.objective: Design a hypothetical planet on which days have irregular lengths

inertia_conceptual_review.title: Inertia Conceptual Review
inertia_conceptual_review.objectives: Give conceptual examples of inertia in linear situations.

rotational_dynamics_analogies.title: Rotational Dynamics Analogies
rotational_dynamics_analogies.objective: Draw analogies between linear dynamic quantities and formulas and rotational dynamic quantities and formulas; define torque and rotational inertia

rotational_inertia_formula.title: Rotational Inertia Formula
rotational_inertia_formula.objective: Use the formula for rotational inertia to find rotational inertia of a point masses.

cross_product.title: Cross Products
cross_product.objective: Determine the vector cross product of two vectors; practice using right hand rules.

torque_formula.title: The Torque Formula
torque_formula.objective: Use the formula for torque to find the torque in situations with forces acting on a stick.

rigid_bodies.title: Rigid Bodies
rigid_bodies.objective: Define rigid and identify rigid bodies and non-rigid bodies; explain the significance of rigid bodies

rotational_dynamic_dimensional_analysis.title: Rotational Dynamic Dimensional Analysis
rotational_dynamic_dimensional_analysis.objective: Determine the dimensions of all rotational dynamic quantities, particularly torque and rotational inertia

rotational_inertia_conceptual_examples.title: Rotational Inertia Conceptual Examples
rotational_inertia_conceptual_examples.objective: Explain several conceptual examples of items with different rotational inertia
examples: Why is it easier to balance a meter stick with a weight on the end?
Why does a disc roll faster than a hoop of the same mass?
Why does liquid soup roll faster than cream soup, but cream soup faster still than noodle soup?

torque_concepts.title: Torque Concepts
torque_concepts.objective: Use the concept of torque to analyze real world situations

same_force_different_torque.title: Same Force Different Torque
same_force_different_torque.objective: Identify and explain times when the same force acting in different directions and locations results in different torques on a rotating object; describe why a lineman must hit low to make a good block.

torque_conceptual_examples.title: Torque Conceptual Examples
torque_conceptual_examples.objective: Give real world examples of when torque is a crucial concept.

torque_with_cross_product.title: Torque with Cross Product
torque_with_cross_product.objective: Use the torque formula in situations requiring a single cross product; determine angular acceleration.

determine_net_torque.title: Determine Net Torque
determine_net_torque.objective: For a rotating object experiencing multiple torques, some forces applied at a non-perpendicular angle, determine the net torque acting on the object.

determine_angular_acceleration.title: Determine Angular Acceleration
determine_angular_acceleration.objective: For a rotating object experiencing multiple torques, some requiring cross products, determine the net torque acting on the object and the angular acceleration of the object.

basic_rolling.title: Basic Rolling
basic_rolling.objective: Draw free-body diagrams and analyze the torque of a rolling object; identify the type of friction that causes rolling; differentiate between rolling with and without slipping.

rolling_down_a_hill.title: Rolling down a Hill
rolling_down_a_hill.objective: Numerically determine the free-body diagram, torque, angular acceleration and linear acceleration of a ball rolling down a hill.

numerical_car_tire.title: Numerical Car Tire
numerical_car_tire.objective: Numerically determine the free-body diagram, torque, angular acceleration and linear acceleration of a spinning car tire.

weight_hanging_numerical.title: Numerical Weight Hanging
weight_hanging_numerical.objective: Numerically determine the free-body diagram, torque, angular acceleration and [where necessary] linear acceleration of a wheel with a weight hanging from it.

raiders_of_the_lost_arc.title: Raiders of the Lost Arc
raiders_of_the_lost_arc.objective: Analyze why the giant ball designed to roll and kill Indiana Jones failed to do so, and redesign the setup to accomplish this task.
raiders_of_the_lost_arc.notes: Extra credit will be awarded if quiz is accomplished while wearing a fedora and humming Indiana Jones theme.

derivation_newtons_second_law_rotation.title: Derivation of Newton's Second Law for Rotation
derivation_newtons_second_law_rotation.objective: Derive Newton's Second Law for Rotational Motion, including in cases when the forces are applied at non-perpendicular angles.

wheel_of_fortune.title: Wheel of Fortune
wheel_of_fortune.objective: Design a mathematical model to predict where the wheel of fortune will land after having been spun.
wheel_of_fortune.notes: Includes making some basic assumption about torques acting on the wheel; will probably need to use the concept of rotational impulse

rotational_conserved_quantities_1.title: Rotational Conserved Quantities 1: Formula Basics
rotational_conserved_quantities_1.objective: Use the formulas for rotational conserved quantities to solve simple numerical questions.

rotational_conservation_analogies.title: Rotational Conservation Analogies
rotational_conservation_analogies.objective: Draw analogies between conserved quantities for linear motion and rotational motion

rotational_conserved_quantities_2.title: Rotational Conserved Quantities 2: Dimensional Analysis and Proportionality
rotational_conserved_quantities_2.objective: Determine the dimensions of all rotation conserved quantities using the formulas to define them; use proportionality to analyze conserved rotational quantities.

angular_momentum_concepts.title: Angular Momentum Concepts
angular_momentum_concepts.objective: Analyze real world situations using the concept of angular momentum.

ice_skater_spin_qualitative.title: Ice Skater Spin Qualitative
ice_skater_spin_qualitative.objective: Using the formulas related to angular momentum, describe how an ice skater (or other athlete) changes her rotational speed.

spirals_knukleballs.title: Spirals and Knuckleballs
spirals_knukleballs.objective: Qualitatively explain the phenomena of a football thrown with a spiral and a knuckleball by referring to the conservation of angular momentum.

ice_skater_spin_quantitative.title: Ice Skater Spin Quantitative
ice_skater_spin_quantitative.objective: Use a quantitative model to predict how much spin will change when a spinner person moves their arms

rotational_kinetic_energy_on_ramp.title: Rotational Kinetic Energy on a Ramp
rotational_kinetic_energy_on_ramp.objective: Describe real-world situations using the conservation of energy, including rotational kinetic energy.
examples: A block sliding without friction goes faster than a wheel
Why do the dynamics cars have small wheels?

rotation_work_energy_theorem.title: Rotation and the Work-Energy Theorem
rotation_work_energy_theorem.objective: Analyze situations including rotational kinetic energy using the work-energy theorem.

rotational_kinetic_energy_different_poin.title: Rotational Kinetic Energy from Different Points of View
rotational_kinetic_energy_different_poin.objective: Analyze situations including rotational kinetic energy using different definitions of the system and surroundings
rotational_kinetic_energy_different_poin.example: A ball rolls down a ramp; analyze the types of energy in which only the ball is the system and when there is a ball-earth system.

reinvent_the_wheel.title: Reinvent the Wheel
reinvent_the_wheel.objective: Compare how energy changes in a block sliding down a ramp with friction and a wheel rolling down the same ramp; make a conclusion regarding the use of wheels.

precession_of_axes.title: Precession of Axes
precession_of_axes.objective: Use conservation of angular momentum to explain why the earth's axes precess and the consequences of this precession.

electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.title: Electromagnetic vs. Mechanical Waves 1
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.objective: Recognize electromagnetic and mechanical waves from a list; answer multiple choice questions on differences between electromagnetic and mechanical waves.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.content: All waves can be categorized as either electromagnetic waves or mechanical waves.

transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.title: Transverse vs. Longitudinal Waves
transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.objective: Differentiate between pictures and examples of transverse and longitudinal waves.
transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.content: All waves can be categorized as either transverse or longitudinal waves.

parts_of_a_wave_1.title: Parts of a Wave 1: Transverse Waves
