parts_of_a_wave_1.objective: Identify important parts of a traveling transverse wave, including crests, troughs, wavelength, and amplitude.
parts_of_a_wave_1.content: Crests, troughs, wavelength, and amplitude are important elements of a transverse wave.

drawing_waves_1A.title: Drawing Waves 1A: Wavelength
drawing_waves_1A.objective: Draw transverse waves with a particular wavelength and each crest correctly positioned
drawing_waves_1A.content: The distance between the crests of a transverse wave show its wavelength.

drawing_waves_1B.title: Drawing Waves 1B: Amplitude
drawing_waves_1B.objective: Draw transverse waves with a particular amplitude.
drawing_waves_1B.content: The distance from the middle of a transverse wave to its crest shows its amplitude.

wave_equation.title: The Wave Equation
wave_equation.objective: Use the equation v = lambda f in simple contexts related to waves.
wave_equation.content: The speed of a wave is equal to its wavelength times its frequency.

electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.title: Electromagnetic vs. Mechanical Waves 2
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.objective: Write definitions of electromagnetic and mechanical waves; write differences between electromagnetic and mechanical waves.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.notes: This is the quiz in which students formally define a wave.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.content: Mechanical waves consist of moving oscillations; electromagnetic wave consist of oscillating electric and magnetic energy.

oscillation_particles_during_wave.title: Oscillation of Particles During a Wave
oscillation_particles_during_wave.objective: Diagram how an object oscillates as a mechanical transverse or longitudinal wave passes through.
oscillation_particles_during_wave.content: As a wave passes through, the direction a particle oscillates depends on whether it is a transverse or mechanical wave.

wave_categorization.title: Wave Categorization
wave_categorization.objective: Categorize waves using a matrix as electromagnetic or mechanical and as longitudinal or transverse.
wave_categorization.content: Waves can be categorized as transverse electromagnetic waves, transverse mechanical waves, or longitudinal mechanical waves.

parts_of_a_wave_2.title: Parts of a Wave 2: Longitudinal Waves
parts_of_a_wave_2.objective: Identify parts of a longitudinal wave, including compression zone, rarefaction zone, and wavelength; briefly measure wavelength and amplitude of a longitudinal wave.
parts_of_a_wave_2.content: The crest of a transverse wave corresponds to the compression zone of a longitudinal wave; the trough of a longitudinal wave corresponds to the rarefaction zone of a longitudinal wave; wavelength and amplitude can be measured on an image of a longitudinal wave.

speed_of_sound_and_light_1.title: Speed of Sound and Light 1
speed_of_sound_and_light_1.objective: Identify the difference between the speeds of sound and light; identify real world implications of this.
speed_of_sound_and_light_1.content: Sound moves much slower than light, and this fact can be observed whenever a loud sound is made far away.

drawing_waves_2.title: Drawing Waves 2: Wavelength and amplitude
drawing_waves_2.objective: Draw waves of particular wavelength AND amplitude, with a particular focus on the crests of a wave.
drawing_waves_2.limits: Grading is generous if the troughs of a wave are not perfectly drawn.
drawing_waves_2.content: Wavelength and amplitude can be depicted on an image of a wave.

making_transverse_longitudinal_waves.title: Making Transverse and Longitudinal Waves
making_transverse_longitudinal_waves.objective: Explain how to create transverse and longitudinal waves in multiple contexts; explain logically why sound is longitudinal and light is transverse.
making_transverse_longitudinal_waves.content: Transverse waves are created by particles pulling the particles behind them; longitudinal waves are created by particles pushing the particles in front of them

drawing_waves_3.title: Drawing Waves 3: Crests and Troughs positioned
drawing_waves_3.objective: Draw waves of particular wavelength AND amplitude with every crest, trough, and center point correctly positioned.
drawing_waves_3.content: The wavelength should be the distance from crest to crest, from trough to trough, and twice then length from center point to center point; each trough should be halfway between two crests and vice versa; each center point should be evenly between a crest and a trough.
drawing_waves_3.note: Crest, troughs, and middle points must all be correctly positioned, horizontally and vertically, for full credit.

speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.title: Speed of Sound and Light in Media
speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.objective: Identify how media change the speed of sound and the speed of light; identify why media has opposite effects on the speed of sound and of light.
speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.content: Sound moves faster in dense media because closer together particles can push each other quickly and more efficiently; light moves faster in less dense media because electromagnetic waves do not depend on media and any particles are in the way of the wave's progress.
speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.notes: Also deals with the ideas of transverse and longitudinal waves..

trigonometric_waves_1.title: Trigonometric Waves 1
trigonometric_waves_1.objective: Write trigonometric functions that show the shape of a wave with a particular wavelength and amplitude
trigonometric_waves_1.content: Waves can be modeled mathematically as sine or cosine functions

drawing_waves_4.title: Drawing Waves 4: Phase
drawing_waves_4.objective: Draw waves with a particular wavelength, amplitude, and phase, with all crests, troughs, and center points drawn correctly.
drawing_waves_4.content: The phase of a wave indicates at what point in a cycle that wave begins.
drawing_waves_4.notes: The wave must begin on a particular phase for full credit. Phases presented are 0, pi/2, pi, and 3pi/2

trigonometric_waves_2.title: Trigonometric Waves 2
trigonometric_waves_2.objective: Write trigonometric functions that show the shape of a wave with a particular wavelength and amplitude
trigonometric_waves_2.content: Wavelength can be represented as a divider within a trigonometric function; amplitude can be represented by a multiplier outside the trigonometric function.

trigonometric_waves_3.title: Trigonometric Waves 3
trigonometric_waves_3.objective: Write a trigonometric function that gives the position of a particle relative to time as a transverse wave passes through. Identify and explain pieces of this function.
trigonometric_waves_3.content: A traveling wave is represented by both a position and time term within a trigonometric function.

combined_transverse_longitudinal_waves.title: Combined Transverse-Longitudinal Waves
combined_transverse_longitudinal_waves.objective: Qualitatively analyze waves that combine transverse and longitudinal elements.
combined_transverse_longitudinal_waves.content: Mechanical waves can combine transverse and longitudinal elements; particles move in circles when these waves pass through.

trigonometric_waves_4.title: Trigonometric Waves 4
trigonometric_waves_4.objective: Write a trigonometric function that gives the position of a particle relative to time as a longitudinal wave passes through. Identify and explain pieces of this function.
trigonometric_waves_4.content: A traveling wave is represented as a trigonometric function with both a time term and a position term inside.

trigonometric_waves_5.title: Trigonometric Waves 5
trigonometric_waves_5.objective: Write a trigonometric function that gives the position of a particle relative to time as a combined transverse/longitudinal wave passes through. Identify and explain pieces of this function.
trigonometric_waves_5.content: Phase is represented by another term within a trigonometric function, or by using a different trigonometric function.

traveling_vs_standing_waves.title: Traveling vs. Standing Waves
traveling_vs_standing_waves.objective: Identify examples of and differences between traveling and standing wave; identify parts of a standing wave.
traveling_vs_standing_waves.content: Traveling waves move from one point to another; standing wave have the shape of a wave but are actually oscillators between two points; a node is a

finding_wavelength_from_diagrams.title: Finding Wavelength from Diagrams
finding_wavelength_from_diagrams.objective: From a of waves of a given length, find the wavelength of the wave; includes fractional wavelengths
finding_wavelength_from_diagrams.content: A wavelength is equal to the length required for one full cycle of a wave; a physicist can use this principle to find wavelength from a diagram of a wave

wave_formula_2.title: The Wave Formula 2
wave_formula_2.objective: Use the formula relating the wavelength, speed, and frequency of a wave
wave_formula_2.content: The speed of a wave is equal to its frequency times its wavelength

harmonics_1.title: Harmonics 1
harmonics_1.subtitle: Drawing Harmonics on a String with two Closed Ends
harmonics_1.objective: Draw a simple sequence of harmonics on a string with two closed ends
harmonics_1.content: All of the harmonics on a string with two closed ends have a node at the end.

harmonics_2.title: Harmonics 2
harmonics_2.subtitle: Analyzing Harmonics with a Table
harmonics_2.objective: Using a table, draw a series of harmonics on a string with two closed ends to find the wavelength and frequency of each; define the fundamental frequency; also analyze harmonics in a tube with two closed ends or two open ends.
harmonics_2.content: The wavelengths of harmonics on a string have a defined pattern that can be determined from the diagrams; the frequencies of each harmonic can be determined from combining this pattern with the relevant formula; the fundamental frequency is the frequency of the first harmonic; ina tube, harmonics move at the speed of sound; there is always an antinode at open ends and a node at closed ends of a tube.

harmonics_3.title: Harmonics 3
harmonics_3.subtitle: Quarter Wavelength Harmonics
harmonics_3.objective: Using a table, draw a series of harmonics and find the wavelength and frequency of each; harmonics include a node on one end and an antinode on the other.
harmonics_3.content: When one end of a tube is open and the other is closed, the wavelengths follow a pattern of quarter wavelengths instead of half wavelengths

harmonics_4.title: Harmonics 4: Harmonics Unguided Math
harmonics_4.objective: Given quantitative information on a single harmonic, find similar information on another harmonic.
harmonics_4.content: By working out the pattern of how wavelengths and frequencies of harmonics are related, physicists can work out the pattern amongst harmonics without filling out a table of all harmonics.

standing_wave_at_times.title: Standing Wave at times
standing_wave_at_times.objective: Draw what a standing wave will look like at each quarter period.
standing_wave_at_times.content: At certain times, the standing wave shows a large pattern of crests and troughs, but at other times the string is actually straight.

harmonics_5.title: Harmonics 5: Symbolic Harmonics
harmonics_5.objective: Create algebraic formulas and an algebraic series that determine the properties of different harmonics.
harmonics_5.content: Harmonics follow a pattern, and this pattern can be described algebraically; physicists can derive new formulas from these patterns.

harmonics_6.title: Harmonics 6: Harmonics Proportionality
harmonics_6.objective: Use proportionality to further analyze harmonics.
harmonics_6.content: Because all harmonics in a tube or string have the same speed, the frequency and wavelength of each harmonic are inversely proportional.

speed_of_sound.title: Speed of Sound
speed_of_sound.objective: Determine the speed of sound by identifying different harmonics.
speed_of_sound.content: Physicists can determine the speed of sound from analyzing the different harmonics made by a tuning fork in an air tube of variable length

string_tension_harmonics.title: String Tension Harmonics
string_tension_harmonics.objective: Analyze harmonics on a string with a different tensions of the string
string_tension_harmonics.content: The speed of a wave in a string is proportional to the square root of the tension of the string; because speed is equal to wavelength times frequency, changing the tension in a string creates differences in the wavelength and frequency of each harmonic.

hanging_string_harmonics.title: Hanging String Harmonics
hanging_string_harmonics.objective: Analyze harmonics in a hanging string.
hanging_string_harmonics.content: The tension a hanging string is greater at the top of the string and lower at the bottom of the string, creating a wave whose speed and wavelength are different at different points on the string.

standing_wave_formation.title: Standing Wave Formation
standing_wave_formation.objective: Show how a standing wave is formed from the interference of many reflecting traveling waves.
standing_wave_formation.content: A standing wave is formed from the interference of many reflecting traveling waves.

musical_instrument.title: Musical Instrument
musical_instrument.objective: Use knowledge of harmonics to design a musical instrument that plays different musical scales.
musical_instrument.content: A musical instrument works with strings or tubes whose fundamental frequencies form different notes on a scale; when a musician creates many harmonics their music sounds better.

speed_of_sound_in_materials.title: Speed of Sound in Materials
speed_of_sound_in_materials.objective: Identify how the speed of sound changes in different media; define the term 'medium' in the content of waves
speed_of_sound_in_materials.content: Sound moves faster in denser materials; sound moves fastest in solids and slowest in gasses; a medium is the material through which a wave moves.

doppler_effect.title: The Doppler Effect
doppler_effect.objective: Identify how the Doppler effect changes sound; identify real world examples of the Doppler effect
doppler_effect.content: When a source of sound moves towards the receiver, it appears to have a higher frequency; when a source of sound moves away from the receiver it appears to have a lower frequency; the same effect occurs if the receiver moves.

octaves_1.title: Octaves 1
octaves_1.objective: Solve for all wavelengths and frequencies of a particular octave, with notes given.
octaves_1.content: An octave is eight notes within a musical scale; the highest note of any octave has twice the frequency of the lowest note.

octaves_2.title: Octaves 2: Musical Scales
octaves_2.objective: Solve for all wavelengths and frequencies of a particular octave, with ratios of the octave given.
octaves_2.content: The eight notes of an octave are related by particular ratios of frequencies that allow music made within that scale to be more pleasing to the ear.

doppler_effect_equation.title: Doppler Effect Equation
doppler_effect_equation.objective: Numerically solve the Doppler effect equation and relate the result to a real life experience.
doppler_effect_equation.content: The Doppler effect equation is used to calculate the apparent frequency of sound from a moving source, or sound heard by a moving receiver.

doppler_diagrams.title: Doppler Diagrams
doppler_diagrams.objective: Analyze diagrams of a wave front of sound; explain why the Doppler effect occurs.
doppler_diagrams.content: Sound waves can be represented by a series of circles indicating the wave fronts of the sound; the Doppler effect occurs because the sound waves get closer together or farther apart due to motion of the source of receiver

explain_speed_of_sound.title: Explain The Speed of Sound
explain_speed_of_sound.objective: Explain why the speed of sound changes within different media.
explain_speed_of_sound.content: Because sound is a longitudinal wave that exists because each molecule pushes the molecule in front of it; more dense materials cause sound to move faster and more efficiently

doppler_algebra.title: Doppler Algebra
doppler_algebra.objective: Symbolically solve the Doppler effect equation.
doppler_algebra.content: New equations can be derived by symbolically solving the Doppler equation.

doppler_proportionality.title: Doppler Proportionality
doppler_proportionality.objective: Use proportionality to analyze the Doppler effect equation.
doppler_proportionality.content: The Doppler equation can be used to relate quantities such as the speed of the source or receiver to the frequency of sound heard.

sound_barrier.title: The Sound Barrier
sound_barrier.objective: Use diagrams of sound waves to explain the existence of the sound barrier, and what occurs when it is broken.
sound_barrier.content: The sound barrier exists because a source of sound moving near the speed of sound begins to catch up with the wave fronts it produces; the wave fronts are high density regions of air, creating the feeling of a wall or barrier

wave_phenomena.title: Wave Phenomena
wave_phenomena.notes: Potentially: Reflection and refraction should be separated from diffraction and interference; 8-22-19 DEFINITELY necessary
wave_phenomena.more notes: There's alot missing, is there anything on the speed of light and the index of refraction...AP needs interference but not reflection and refraction

wave_phenomena_basics.title: Wave Phenomena Basics
wave_phenomena_basics.objective: Identify real-world examples of reflection, refraction, interference, scattering, diffraction, and absorption of waves.
wave_phenomena_basics.content: When a wave crosses from one medium to another, it can undergo a phenomenon such as reflection, refraction, interference, scattering, diffraction, or absorption.

reflection_diagram_1.title: Reflection Diagram 1: Identification
reflection_diagram_1.objective: Given a diagram of reflection, identify elements of the diagrams. Identify the law of reflection
reflection_diagram_1.content: When a ray of light strikes a barrier and reflections, a physicist can identify the incident ray, reflected ray, angle of incidence and angle of reflection; the angle of incidence always equals the angle of reflection.

reflection_diagram_2.title: Reflection Diagram 2: From Memory
reflection_diagram_2.objective: From memory, create diagrams A diagram of reflection. Demonstrate that this diagram illustrates the law of reflection.
reflection_diagram_2.content:: When a ray of light strikes a barrier and reflections, a physicist can diagram the incident ray, reflected ray, angle of incidence and angle of reflection; the angle of incidence always equals the angle of reflection.

refraction_diagrams_1.title: Refraction Diagrams 1: Identification
refraction_diagrams_1.objective: Given a diagram of refraction, identify elements of the diagrams. Indicate whether light speeds of slows in the situation and what it could represent.
refraction_diagrams_1.content: When a ray of light enters a new medium and bends, a physicist can identify the incident ray, refracted ray, the angle of incidence, and the angle of refraction; if the light speeds up it bends outward and the angle of refraction is greater than the angle of incidence; if the light slows down in bends inward and the angle of refraction is less than the angle of incidence.

refraction_diagrams_2.title: Refraction Diagrams 2: From Memory
refraction_diagrams_2.objective: Given a diagram of refraction, identify elements of the diagrams. Indicate whether light speeds of slows in the situation and what it could represent.
refraction_diagrams_2.content: When a ray of light enters a new medium and bends, a physicist can diagram the incident ray, refracted ray, the angle of incidence, and the angle of refraction; if the light speeds up it bends outward and the angle of refraction is greater than the angle of incidence; if the light slows down in bends inward and the angle of refraction is less than the angle of incidence.
refraction_diagrams_2.idea: should the quiz not indicate whether light must speed or slow, and leave that to be identified separately?

diffraction_scattering_diagrams.title: Diffraction and Scattering Diagrams
diffraction_scattering_diagrams.objective: Draw diagrams that illustrate the phenomena of diffraction and scattering.
diffraction_scattering_diagrams.content: When a wave comes near a corner it bends around the corner; when a wave, particularly light, enters certain medium, it is scattered in many different directions.

interference_diagrams_1.title: Interference Diagrams 1: Interference in Regularly Shaped Waves
interference_diagrams_1.objective: Draw and recognize diagrams that show examples of normally-shaped waves passing through each other.
interference_diagrams_1.content: When two waves intersect, they pass through each other without affecting each other, and as they do they sum together to make a different shaped wave.

interference_diagrams_2.title: Interference Diagrams 2: Interference in Non-Regularly Shaped Waves
interference_diagrams_2.objective: Draw and recognize diagrams that show non-regular examples of waves passing through each other.
interference_diagrams_2.content: When two waves interfere, they sum together; if the two waves are irregularly shaped they make new shapes that are often unpredictable.

wave_diagrams_3.title: Wave Diagrams 3: Multiple Instances of Reflection and Refraction
wave_diagrams_3.objective: Draw and label diagrams that include multiple instances of reflection and refraction.
wave_diagrams_3.content: A ray of light can reflect off one surface and then refract through another, creating a pattern that is less obvious, but that can be tracked.

snells_law_basic.title: Snell's Law Basic
snells_law_basic.objective: Draw and label quantitative diagrams of refraction using Snell's Law.
snells_law_basic.content: Snell's Law is a formula that allows a physicist to predict at what angle a light way will refract from the index of refraction of the materials the light crosses through.

huygens_principle.title: Huygen's Principle
huygens_principle.objective: Use and diagram Huygen's Principle to explain why refraction occurs.
huygens_principle.content: Huygen's Principle states that every point on a wavefront  can be considered a new source of wavefronts; Huygen's principle can illustrate why a wave curves around a barrier.

diffraction_grating_diagram.title: Diffraction Grating Diagrams
diffraction_grating_diagram.objective: Draw diagrams that illustrate interference patterns as light travels through a diffraction grating.
diffraction_grating_diagram.content: When light travels through a pattern of small holes, it first diffracts, then diffracted wavefronts interfere to create a pattern of dots or bands.

snells_law_prism.title: Snell's Law Prism
snells_law_prism.objective: Use Snell's law to explain how a prism splits light into colors.
snells_law_prism.content: Each wavelength of light has a slightly different index of refraction in glass and water, causing each wavelength to bend at a different angle and spread out all colors.

finding_speed_of_light.title: Finding the speed of light
finding_speed_of_light.objective: Explain how the speed of light can be determined.
finding_speed_of_light.content: The speed of light can be determined by having two beams travel different distances and interfere, causing a difference in phase that can be measured.
finding_speed_of_light.notes: Should be moved to lab unit?

diffraction_grating_formula.title: Diffraction Grating Formula
diffraction_grating_formula.objective: Use the diffraction grating formula to derive the wavelength of light.
diffraction_grating_formula.content: By studying the patterns of dots and bands produced when light travels through a diffraction grating, a physicist can derive a formula for the wavelength of specific colors of light.

discovery_of_dna_structure.title: Discovery of the DNA Structure
discovery_of_dna_structure.objective: Using a diagram of X-Ray diffraction, describe the structure of DNA and defend your answer.
discovery_of_dna_structure.content: The pattern of a DNA molecules was determined by seeing the interference pattern made by X-Rays diffracting as they crossed through the bands of DNA.

rainbows_quantitative.title: Rainbows Quantitative
rainbows_quantitative.objective: Use Snell's Law and diagrams of refraction and reflection to quantitatively and qualitatively explain how a rainbow is made from raindrops.
rainbows_quantitative.content: A physicist can use Snell's law and the laws of reflection to create a quantitative model of how a rainbow exists.

the_electromagnetic_spectrum_quantitativ.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum: Quantitative
enduring_understandings: The electromagnetic spectrum contains seven types of electromagnetic waves, including visible light.
While all waves are experienced and applied in qualitatively different waves, they are all the same thing: oscillating electric and magnetic energy.
The only true differences amongst electromagnetic waves are quantitative values: wavelength, frequency, and photon energy
These three values are related by fundamental constants.
Frequency and energy are directly proportional, while wavelength is inversely proportional to both.

electromagnetic_wave_basics.title: Electromagnetic Wave Basics
electromagnetic_wave_basics.objective: Remember basic facts about electromagnetic waves.
electromagnetic_wave_basics.content: Electromagnetic waves are oscillations of electric and magnetic energy; all electromagnetic waves move at 300,000,000 m/s; electromagnetic waves can move through vacuums; electromagnetic waves are transverse.

electromagnetic_spectrum_1.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum 1
electromagnetic_spectrum_1.objective: Memorize the Electromagnetic Spectrum and the colors separately in order from longest to shortest wavelength; relate different waves using the terms wavelength and frequency
electromagnetic_spectrum_1.content: Each color has a specific wavelength and frequency that defines that color; each type of electromagnetic wave has a specific wavelength and frequency that define that wave; wavelength and frequency are inversely proportional

choosing_color_by_wavelength.title: Choosing Colors by Wavelength
choosing_color_by_wavelength.objective: For visible electromagnetic waves of specific wavelengths, determine the color of that wave.
choosing_color_by_wavelength.content: The wavelength of each electromagnetic wave determines what color that wave is; visible light spans from 400 nm to 700 nm

electromagnetic_spectrum_2.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum 2
electromagnetic_spectrum_2.objective: Memorize the Electromagnetic Spectrum and colors as a single spectrum in order from longest to shortest wavelength; relate different waves using the terms wavelength, frequency, and energy (short answer).
electromagnetic_spectrum_2.content: The electromagnetic spectrum can be broken into six invisible waves and six visible colors; these categories have different wavelength, frequency, and energy; all electromagnetic waves have the same speed.

classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.title: Classify Electromagnetic Wave by Wavelength 1
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.subtitle: Scientific Notation
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.objective: Given a wave of a particular wavelength of any order of magnitude, determine what type of electromagnetic wave is represented.
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.limits: All values are given in SI scientific notation and not in metric units
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.content: Any electromagnetic wave is categorized into a particular type by its wavelength; wavelength can span from over one meter to 10^-12 m, so a through knowledge of scientific notation is necessary to properly categorize waves.

classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.title: Classify Electromagnetic Wave by Wavelength 2
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.subtitle: Metric Units
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.objective: Given a wave of a particular wavelength of any order of magnitude, determine what type of electromagnetic wave is represented.
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.content: The wavelength of an electromagnetic wave can is frequently expressed in metric units; by understanding these metric units a physicist can better classify electromagnetic waves.

photon_formulas_1.title: Photon Formulas 1
photon_formulas_1.objective: Quantitatively relate wavelength, frequency, and photon energy of a wave; problems presented step by step
photon_formulas_1.content: Physicists use two key formulas to relate the wavelength, frequency, and energy of an electromagnetic photon.

electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.title: Electromagnetic Wave Proportionality
electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.objective: Relate wavelength, frequency, and energy of waves using proportionality rules.
electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.content: The energy of an electromagnetic photon is directly proportional to its frequency and inversely proportional to its wavelength; a physicist can use these relationships to better comprehend electromagnetic waves.

photon_formulas_2.title: Photon Formulas 2
photon_formulas_2.objective: Quantitatively relate wavelength, frequency, and photon energy of a wave; problems are asked in all directions in tabular form
photon_formulas_2.content: Because the wavelength, frequency, and energy electromagnetic photons comprise such as wide range of magnitudes, rarely used metric units are frequently used to express them; these units must be properly converted before and after using any formula

logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.title: Logarithmic Graph of the Electromagnetic Spectrum 1
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.objective: Create a logarithmic axis which shows the range of each type of electromagnetic wave with scales in terms of ONE of the following: wavelength, energy, and frequency; express the logarithmic value on the axis
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.content: Due to the wide range of wavelengths in the electromagnetic spectrum, the electromagnetic spectrum can only be properly visualized on a logarithmic scale

logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.title: Logarithmic Graph of the EM Spectrum 2
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.objective: Create a logarithmic axis which shows the range of each type of electromagnetic wave with scales in terms of ALL THREE of the following: wavelength, energy, and frequency; express graph using a logarithmic scale but numbers written in linear
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.content: A logarithmic scale can be used to describe the electromagnetic spectrum using either wavelength, frequency, or photon energy as a categorizing quantity.

space_photos.title: Space Photos
space_photos.objective: Explain, and do some examples, how photos are made of non-visible light objects in space.
space_photos.content: NASA and similar organizations collect vast amounts of numerical data from telescopes; beautiful photos that are publicized as space are often constructed by correlating invisible electromagnetic wavelengths to visible ones.

visible_light_human_experience.title: Visible Light and the Human Experience
visible_light_human_experience.objective: From your knowledge of the electromagnetic spectrum, surmise philosophical conclusions on the human experience and the role of humans in the universe.
visible_light_human_experience.content: The human eye reacts to an almost immeasurably  tiny portion of the electromagnetic spectrum; philosophers seeking to understand humanity's place int he universe must contend with this fact.

the_electromagnetic_spectrum_conceptual.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum: Conceptual
notes: I still need to add goals related to additive and subtractive processes

basic_infrared_camera.title: Basic Infrared Camera
basic_infrared_camera.objective: Explain how an infrared camera produces images; explain using the language of electromagnetic waves and not of 'seeing heat'.
basic_infrared_camera.content: An infrared camera records the prescence of infrared waves; because infrared waves are given off by warmer objects, warmer objects such as people appear brighter in an infrared camera.
examples: Why do humans appear white on an infrared camera?
Why does ice appear black on an infrared camera?

reflection_color.title: Reflection and Color
reflection_color.objective: Predict how objects of different color will reflect different photons of light.
reflection_color.content: Objects with a color reflect the color of light they are and absorb other colors; white objects reflect all photons and black objects absorb all photons.

additive_color.title: Additive Color
additive_color.objective: Explain how colors of light combine to make different colors; relate this fact to light from the sun and flourescent lights
additive_color.content: All colors of light combined create white light; humans see red, blue, and green photons with their photoreceptors; red and green light appear yellow; red and blue light appear fuscia; green and blue light appaer cyan.

long_vs_short_wavelength.title: Long vs. Short Wavelength
long_vs_short_wavelength.objective: Identify long and short wavelength electromagnetic waves and explain difference in how they would interact.
long_vs_short_wavelength.content: As a rule of thumb, electromagnetic waves of long wavelength are 'tougher' and more able to move through materials unhindered; electromagnetic waves of short wavelength are 'weaker' and are more likely to be absorbed or scattered.

infrared_camera_advanced.title: Infrared Camera Advanced
infrared_camera_advanced.objective: Explain how different objects emit different wavelengths
infrared_camera_advanced.content: Warmer objects emit higher frequency infrared waves, and the warmest emit visible light waves.
examples: The wires inside a toaster appear red, why?
How are the wires inside of a toaster similar to humans, how are they different, and how can different types of camera examine this difference.
How do objects of different human color appear on an infrared camera?

safe_dangerous_radiation.title: Safe and dangerous radiation
safe_dangerous_radiation.objective: Define the terms 'radiation' and 'electromagnetic radiations,' differentiate between ionizing radiation and non-ionizing radiation; identify the health risks associated with ionizing radiation.
safe_dangerous_radiation.content: All photons with an energy greater than 13.6 eV (in the ultraviolet range) are capable of turning an neutral atom into an ion, whick creates health risks in human bodies; the term 'radiation' in physics means all electromagnetic waves, many of which are not dangerous.

subtractive_color.title: Subtractive Color
subtractive_color.objective: Explain how colors of paint combine and relate this to knowledge about how light combines and how reflection produces color.
subtractive_color.content: Paint works by absorbing and reflecting different colors; rules of mixing paint are thus different (and somewhat opposite) as the rules of mixing light.

identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.title: Identify Applications of Electromagnetic Waves
identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.objective: In writing, identify human applications each of types of invisible electromagnetic waves; relate the particular uses of each wave to wavelength, frequency and energy
identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.content: Humans use long and short wavelength electromagnetic waves for many different applications.
identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.notes: should be split into long and short wavelength
examples: What types of wave are most used for communication and why?
How does X-rays allow you to see within your body?
Which types of waves are dangerous and why?
Can dangerous waves be useful, and how.

long_wavelength_astronomy.title: Long Wavelength Astronomy
long_wavelength_astronomy.objective: Explain how astronomers conduct astronomy in the radio, microwave and infrared ranges and what objects they see in these ranges.
long_wavelength_astronomy.content: Radio and microwave astronomy are very crucial to cosmology and can be conducted easily from earth; infrared astronomy is crucial to studying the interstellar medium and is conducted via satellite

short_wavelength_astronomy.title: Short Wavelength Astronomy
short_wavelength_astronomy.objective: Explain how astronomers conduct astronomy in the visible, ultraviolet, X-Ray and gamma ray ranges and what objects they see in these ranges.
short_wavelength_astronomy.content: Space telescopes that see visible, ultraviolet, and X-Rays are able to collect far more information about the makeup for astronomical bodies; gamma ray observations can learn about gamma ray burts or cosmic gamma rays

why_is_the_sky_blue.title: Why is the sky blue?
why_is_the_sky_blue.objective: Use basic principles of electromagnetic waves, especially long and short wavelengths, and human vision to explain why the sky is blue; explain why oceans are blue and sunsets are orange.
why_is_the_sky_blue.content: The sky is blue because blue photons are scattered by the atmosphere; our eyes are more sensitive to blue photons than violet photons; oceans are blue because light reflects off the water; sunsets are orange because longer wavelength photons are scattered if light must travel through more of the atmosphere.

climate_change.title: Climate Change
climate_change.objective: Explain why the greenhouse effect occurs and explain positive and negative results of the greenhouse effect.
climate_change.content: The atmosphere absorbs and re-emits infrared radiation given off by earth, raising earth's temperature; without this effect, earth would be too cold for humans to live; more CO2 an CH4 in the atomspehre will cause more radiation to be absobred and re-emitted, raising earth's average temperature.

galaxy_in_all_wavelengths.title: A Galaxy in All Wavelengths
galaxy_in_all_wavelengths.objective: Examine photos of astronomical bodies in each region of the electromagnetic spectrum.
galaxy_in_all_wavelengths.content: To study a single galaxy in all wavelengths gives significant knowledge about the makeup of each galaxy.

electromagnetic_rube_goldberg_device.title: Electromagnetic Rube Goldberg Device
electromagnetic_rube_goldberg_device.objective: Design a hypothetical device that uses each different type of electromagnetic wave to accomplish a small household task.
electromagnetic_rube_goldberg_device.content: Electromagnetic waves of different wavelengths can trigger different sensors.

lens_1.title: Lens 1: Convex Lens Object Outside Focal Length
lens_1.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a convex lens with an object outside the focal length.
lens_1.content: A ray diagram shows an object and a lens; all rays that are parallel to the lens go through the focal point on the other side; where multiple rays converge an image is seen.

mirror_1.title: Mirror 1: Concave Mirror Object Outside Focal Range
mirror_1.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a concave mirror with an object inside the focal range
mirror_1.content: A ray diagram shows an object an a mirror; all rays that are parallel to the mirror reflect through the focal point; where multiple rays intersect an image is seen.

lens_mirror_equations_1.title: Lens and Mirror Equations 1
lens_mirror_equations_1.objective: Predict the location of an image from the position of an object and the focal length of a lens or mirror.
lens_mirror_equations_1.content: The lens and mirror equations relate the position of an object and the focal length of a lens or mirror to the position of an image.

lens_mirror_equations_2.title: Lens and Mirror Equations 2
lens_mirror_equations_2.objective: Given the location and height of an object and the focal length of a lens or mirror, predict the location of the image, the height of the image, if the image is real or virtual, if the image is upright or inverted
lens_mirror_equations_2.content: The lens and mirror equations relate the position of an object and the focal length of a lens or mirror to the position and magnification of an image.

lens_2.title: Lens 2: Convex Lens Object Inside Focal Range
lens_2.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a convex lens with an object inside the focal range
lens_2.content: If two rays do not intersect in a ray diagram, then they can be traced back to a point where they virtually intersect and create a virtual image.

mirror_2.title: Mirror 2: Concave Mirror Object inside of Focal Range
mirror_2.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a concave mirror with an object inside the focal range
mirror_2.content: Virtual images can appear in mirrors as well as lenses.

lens_3.title: Lens 3: Concave Lenses
lens_3.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a concave lens with an object inside or outside of the focal range
lens_3.content: A concave lens follows similar rules to a convex lens, but is more likely to produce an enlarged and virtual image.

mirror_3.title: Mirror 3: Convex Mirrors
mirror_3.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a convex mirror with an object inside or outside of the focal range
mirror_3.content: A convex mirror follows similar rules to a concave mirror, but is more likely to produce an enlarged and virtual image.

lens_4.title: Lens 4: Diagrams and Equations
lens_4.objective: For a convex or concave lenses with the object in all positions, draw a ray diagram and confirm the result of the ray diagrams using the lens equations.
lens_4.content: A ray diagram can be used to manually measure the location and magnification of an image made by a lens, and should return the same result as the lens equation.

mirror_4.title: Mirror 4: Diagrams and Equations
mirror_4.objective: For a convex or concave mirror with the object in all positions, draw a ray diagram and confirm the result of the ray diagrams using the mirror equations.
mirror_4.content: A ray diagram can be used to manually measure the location and magnification of an image made by a mirror, and should return the same result as the mirror equation.

plane_mirrors.title: Plane Mirrors
plane_mirrors.objective: Draw Ray Diagrams for plane mirrors; describe the double speed phenomenon
plane_mirrors.content: A plane mirror create a virtual image that can be measured using the law of reflection; an image of a person walking towards a mirror appears to move at twice the speed the person walks.

multiple_lens_and_mirrors_A.title: Multiple Lenses and Mirrors A
multiple_lens_and_mirrors_A.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a setup involving multiple lenses and mirrors linked together. Confirm this diagram mathces the results given from the equations.
multiple_lens_and_mirrors_A.content: A series of ray diagrams can be used to determine an image made by a sequence of multiple lenses and mirrors.

multiple_lens_and_mirrors_B.title: Multiple Lenses and Mirrors B
multiple_lens_and_mirrors_B.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a setup involving multiple lenses and mirrors linked together. Confirm this diagram mathces the results given from the equations.
multiple_lens_and_mirrors_B.content: A series of ray diagrams can be used to determine an image made by a sequence of multiple lenses and mirrors.

circuit_construction_1.title: Circuit Construction 1
circuit_construction_1.subtitle: Batteries, Light Bulbs, Wires, Resistors, Switches, Fuses

simplest_circuit.title: The Simplest Circuit
simplest_circuit.objective: Light a bulb with one battery, one light bulb, and one wire.
simplest_circuit.content: A single bulb and battery are sufficient to a light a bulb; both ends of the battery must be connected and the light bulb must be within the circuit.

circuit_diagrams_1.title: Circuit Diagrams 1
circuit_diagrams_1.subtitle: Identifying Circuit Components
circuit_diagrams_1.objective: Identify the circuit diagram symbols of batteries, light bulbs, wires, switches, resistors, and fuses
circuit_diagrams_1.content: Circuit diagrams are a standardized way of representing circuits; each element of a circuit is represented by a standardized symbol.

series_vs_parallel.title: Series and Parallel Circuits
series_vs_parallel.objective: Build and draw simple series and parallel circuits correctly; understand advantages and disadvantages of each.
series_vs_parallel.content: A series circuit contains one path for current and a parallel circuit contains multiple paths for current; the number of lines in a symbol for batteries indicates the number of cells in a pack.

short_circuits.title: Short Circuits
short_circuits.objective: Identify and avoid building short circuits
short_circuits.content: A short circuit provides a path with no resistance; short circuits will overheat due to high current and will properly work resistors such as light bulbs.

switches_1.title: Switches 1
switches_1.subtitle: Connecting a Switch
switches_1.objective: Connect a switch that works correctly and does not produce a short circuit.
switches_1.content: A switch must be connected in series with an element to properly control that element.

dimness_brightness_challenges.title: Dimness and Brightness Challenges
dimness_brightness_challenges.objective: Create circuits with multiple light bulbs of different brightness by putting some bulbs in series and some in parallel.
dimness_brightness_challenges.content: Adding light bulbs in series dims all bulbs; light bulbs added in parallel are all bright.

switch_challenges.title: Switch Challenges
switch_challenges.objective: Create complex circuits with multiple switches and light bulbs and predict accurately what each switch will control.
switch_challenges.content: Switches control only circuit elements with which they are in series
switch_challenges.example: Connect three light bulbs and three switches; switch A controls one light bulb; switch B controls two light bulbs; switch C controls all three light bulbs.

fuses.title: Fuses
fuses.objective: Add a fuse to a circuit; explain the value of a fuse; identify the proper location to add a fuse to a circuit.
fuses.content: A fuse burns out if current is too high, breaking a circuit and protecting other elements; fuses should be added where they protect the entire circuit.

breadboards_1.title: Breadboards 1
breadboards_1.subtitle: Understanding a Breadboard
breadboards_1.objective: Understand how a breadboard is connected, make a single bulb light on a breadboard.
breadboards_1.content: A breadboard is a device made of holes connected by wires in a pattern; a breadboard allows physicists to quickly build complex circuits

reading_resistors_1.title: Reading Resistors
reading_resistors_1.objective: Identify the resistance of a resistor from the color bands on the resistor
reading_resistors_1.content: The resistance of a resistor is indicated by the bands of color on that resistor.

combined_challenges.title: Combined Challenges
combined_challenges.objective: Create circuits of switches, fuses, and light bulbs of varying brightness in which each switch controls specified light bulbs.
combined_challenges.content: Combining the positioning of bulbs, fuses, and switches can make complex circuits out of simple parts
combined_challenges.note: Based on the circuit that veronica asked me about in taunton.

voltmeters_ammeters_1.title: Voltmeters and Ammeters 1
voltmeters_ammeters_1.subtitle: Connecting Analog Voltmeters and Ammeters
voltmeters_ammeters_1.objective: Properly connect voltmeters in parallel and ammeters in series
voltmeters_ammeters_1.content: Voltmeters are always connected in parallel with the item they measure; ammeters are always connected in series with the item they measure.

voltmeters_ammeters_2.title: Voltmeters and Ammeters 2
voltmeters_ammeters_2.subtitle: Identify Correct Analog Voltmeters and Ammeters by Range
voltmeters_ammeters_2.objective: From a selection, identify which analog voltmeter or ammeter has the correct range for a particular circuit.
voltmeters_ammeters_2.content: Each meter measures a particular order of magnitude of voltage or current, and a physicists must properly predict which would be used based on understanding the battery and resistor in a circuit.

voltmeters_ammeters_3.title: Voltmeters and Ammeters 3
voltmeters_ammeters_3.subtitle: Using a Multimeter
voltmeters_ammeters_3.objective: Properly use a multimeter as a voltmeter and/or an ammeter.
voltmeters_ammeters_3.content: A multimeter is a device that can be used as a voltmeter or ammeter by turning a knob; the multimeter must still be connected differently when it is connected in different ways.

breadboards_2.title: Breadboards 2
breadboards_2.subtitle: Series and Parallel Circuits on a Breadboard
breadboards_2.objective: Properly create series and parallel circuits on a breadboard
breadboards_2.content: Intimate knowledge of the connections of a breadboard allows physicists to build more complex circuits.

different_switches.title: Different Switches
different_switches.objective: Identifying and use switches that are single or double pull and single or double throw.
different_switches.content: Switches of single or double pull and single or double pull have different effects on a circuit

reading_resistors_2.title: Reading Resistors 2
reading_resistors_2.subtitle: The Fourth Band
reading_resistors_2.objective: Explain and use the fourth color band on a resistor
reading_resistors_2.content: The fourth band of a resistor shows how accurate the other three bands are.

breadboards_3.title: Breadboards 3
breadboards_3.subtitle: Combined Circuits
breadboards_3.objective: Create combined series and parallel circuits off light bulbs and fuses on a breadboard
breadboards_3.content: Intimate knowledge of the connections of a breadboard allows physicists to build more complex circuits

breadboards_4.title: Breadboards 4
breadboards_4.subtitle: Switches on a Breadboard
breadboards_4.objective: Incorporating different types of switches on a breadboard.
breadboards_4.content: Breadboards allow different types of switches to be incorporated into a circuit.

breadboards_5.title: Breadboards 5
breadboards_5.objective: Creating combined series/parallel circuits on a breadboard of resistors of different magnitude in order to achieve and measure particular current and voltage goals.
breadboards_5.content: Combining series and parallel resistors allows a physicist to control the current in different areas of a circuit.

breadboards_6.title: Breadboards 6
breadboards_6.objective: Incorporating different types of switches into the circuits from breadboards 5
breadboards_6.content: Breadboards allow different types of switches to be incorporated into a circuit, adding to its complexity.

advanced_circuit_design.title: Advanced Circuit Design
advanced_circuit_design.objective: Given vague parameters and goals for a particular circuit, build a circuit that accomplishes the goals within the parameters.
advanced_circuit_design.content: An intimate knowledge of the mathematical rules of circuits allows a physicist to build a circuit with particular specifications.

voltage_and_current_concepts.title: Voltage and Current Concepts
voltage_and_current_concepts.note: 8-21-19 i feel like parallel circuit concepts and short circuit concepts belong in a different quiz ladder, and there need to be more quiz ladders on circuits certainly

very_basic_atoms.title: Very Basic Atoms
very_basic_atoms.objective: Draw and explain atomic structure; recognize AC and DC current; explain why specific electrons move
very_basic_atoms.content: Atoms consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons; valence electrons move between atoms in an electric circuit; in a DC current electrons move on one direction while in AC curren they switch directions.

circuit_definitions_1.title: Circuit Definitions 1: Multiple Choice
circuit_definitions_1.objective: Recognize the definitions and properties of voltage, current, resistance, and power.
circuit_definitions_1.content: Voltage is the force that pushes charge around an electric circuit; current is the motion of charge around a circuit; resistance is how difficult it is for charge to move around the circuit; power is the rate at which energy changes form.

insulators_conductors.title: Insulators and Conductors
insulators_conductors.content: Conductors are made of metal and allow electric current to flow; insulators are made of nonmetals and do not allow electric current to flow.

energy_change_in_circuit.title: Energy Change in a Circuit
energy_change_in_circuit.objective: Describe how energy changes in an electric circuit consisting of only a battery, a light bulb, and a wire.
energy_change_in_circuit.content: In an electric circuit, the electrochemical potential energy of a battery becomes electrical energy moving through wires, which then becomes other forms of energy when it reaches a light bulb or resistor.

circuit_definitions_2.title: Circuit Definitions 2: Open Response
circuit_definitions_2.objective: Memorize the definitions and properties of voltage, current, resistance, and power.
circuit_definitions_2.content: Voltage is the force that pushes charge around an electric circuit; current is the motion of charge around a circuit; resistance is how difficult it is for charge to move around the circuit; power is the rate at which energy changes form.

organization_atoms.title: Organization of Atoms
organization_atoms.objective: Draw how atoms are organized in insulators and conductors; relate this organization to how circuits operate within an electric circuit; explain why electrons and not protons and neutrons move in an electric circuit.
organization_atoms.content: In a conductor, valence electrons are shared among a grid of nuclei, allowing charge to flow; in an insulator, valence electrons are held in particular places, making it impossible for charge to flow.

advanced_current_1.title: Advanced Current 1
advanced_current_1.subtitle: How do Electrons Move?
advanced_current_1.objective: Differentiate between two theories of electron motion, one in which electrons all come from the battery and one in which they remain in the wire, select the theory, argue that electrons move slowly through a circuit
advanced_current_1.content: Electrons do not move the whole way around the circuit, but electrons already in a circuit are pushed by the battery.

advanced_voltage_1.title: Advanced Voltage 1
advanced_voltage_1.subtitle: The Potato Battery
advanced_voltage_1.objective: Explain by referring to chemical principles why a potato battery lights a clock; explain why a bulb lights instantly when connected to a battery.
advanced_voltage_1.content: A battery consists of an anode and a cathode connected by a wire and an electrolyte; the anode loses electrons and is oxidized while the cathode gains electrons and is reduced.

advanced_current_2.title: Advanced Current 2
advanced_current_2.subtitle: Implications of How Electrons Move
advanced_current_2.objective: Refer to concepts of how electrons move to explain how current changes in circuits with switches and resistors
advanced_current_2.content: A switch immiedately stops and starts all current in a circuit.
advanced_current_2.note: Address misconception that closer light bulbs will be brighter.

advanced_current_3.title: Advanced Current 3
advanced_current_3.subtitle: Conventional Current
advanced_current_3.objective: Untangle the conundrum that, mathematically, current flows the opposite way that electrons actually move.
advanced_current_3.content: Current represents positive charge motion in the direction opposite that which negative charges move.

advanced_current_4.title: Advanced Current 4
advanced_current_4.subtitle: Electron Drift and Charge of a Wire
advanced_current_4.objective: Describe how electrons combine fast random motion with slow drift under and electric field; describe how an electric wire has a neutral charge.
advanced_current_4.content: Electrons do not flow through a circuit but drift very slowly while also moving randomly; electric wires are not charged when current flows through them.

advanced_current_5.title: Advanced Current 5
advanced_current_5.subtitle: Summation of Charge Motion
advanced_current_5.objective: Describe current and the summation of motion of many charges, relate current to the total number of free-charges in a wire; differentaite between free and not-free electrons in a wire.
advanced_current_5.content: slow motion of countless electrons produces an electric current

advanced_voltage_2.title: Advanced Voltage 2
advanced_voltage_2.subtitle: Battery Chemistry
advanced_voltage_2.objective: Relate specific batteries to half-reactions and explain how electric current flows through the electrolyte
advanced_voltage_2.content: A battery consists of a chemical reaction that involves electron exchange; half of this reaction occurs at the anode and the other half at the cathode; while negative charges move through the wire positive charges move through the electrolyte, creating a complete circuit of positive charge flow.

advanced_current_6.title: Advanced Current 6: Electricity without Electrons
advanced_current_6.objective: Describe how current can flow in bodies with charged particles other than water, such as a solution of ions.
advanced_current_6.content: Any charged particle can be responsible for electric current, not only electrons.

rigorous_definition_current.title: The Rigorous Definition of Current
rigorous_definition_current.objective: Describe current at a point as charge per time through that point; explain an equation that relates electron drift velocity to current.
rigorous_definition_current.content: Current is defined at a given point and is equal to the magnitude of (positive) charge passing that point divided by the time intrval.

rigorous_definition_voltage.title: The Rigorous Definition of Voltage
rigorous_definition_voltage.objective: Describe Potential Difference between two points across a resistor as energy per charge.
rigorous_definition_voltage.content: Voltage (potential difference) is defined as the energy gained or dissipated by a (positive) unit charge between two points.

rigorous_batteries.title: Rigorous Batteries
rigorous_batteries.objective: Apply rigorous definitions of current and voltage to a battery
rigorous_batteries.content: A battery provides electrons on one end, absorbs electrons on the other, and adds a positive potential difference between cathode and anode.

rigorous_definition_power.title: Rigorous Definition of Power
rigorous_definition_power.objective: Describe power as energy inputted or outputted into a circuit per unit time and explain how the power formula is consistent with definitions of current and potential difference.
rigorous_definition_power.content: Power of a circuit represents the energy inputted or outputted per unit time; power is equal to current times voltage.

advanced_current_x.title: Advanced Current 4: Current Model
advanced_current_x.objective: Design a physical model, such as a diagram, a video, or a skit, that accurately describes the motion of electrons on a complex circuit with mulitple resistors and switches in series and parallel.
advanced_current_x.content: A circuit consists of exchange of electrons and positive charges through pushing randomly moving charged particles in a wire, while simultaneously outputting energy for some useful task.

dc_circuit_math_1.title: DC Circuit Math 1: Batteries and Resistors
dc_circuit_math_1.limits: Only contains circuits including batteries and resistors

ohms_law.title: Ohm's Law
ohms_law.objective: Solve Ohm's law for either resistance, current, or voltage.
ohms_law.content: Voltage is equal to current times resistance.

power_formula.title: The Power Formula
power_formula.objective: Use both the power formula and Ohm's Law to solve for power or other quantities.
power_formula.content: Power is equal to current times voltage; this formula can be combined with Ohm's Law.

analyze_circuits_1.title: Analyze Circuits 1
analyze_circuits_1.objective: Use a table to find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of a simple series or parallel circuit; begin from the voltage of the battery and the resistance of each resistor.
analyze_circuits_1.content: Set rules and formulas can find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element of a series or parallel circuit.

analyze_circuits_2.title: Analyze Circuits 2
analyze_circuits_2.objective: Use a table to find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of a simple series or parallel circuit; begin from any information.
analyze_circuits_2.content: Set rules and formulas can find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element of a series or parallel circuit, and you can logically deduce the information you need from different sets of initial information.

algebraic_circuits_1.title: Algebraic Circuits 1
algebraic_circuits_1.subtitle: New Circuit Formulas
algebraic_circuits_1.objective: Know dimensions of voltage, current, resistance, and power; algebraically manipulate and solve Ohm's Law and the Power formula separately and together
algebraic_circuits_1.content: Ohm's Law and the Power Formula can be manipulated to create new formulas.

electric_potential_diagrams_1.title: Electric Potential Diagrams 1
electric_potential_diagrams_1.objective: Draw graphs depicting how electric potential within a circuit changes across each element for simple series and parallel circuits.
electric_potential_diagrams_1.content: Voltage can be depicted as changes in electric potential across a circuit; magnitude of current can also be depicted on an electric potential graph.

analyze_circuits_3.title: Analyze Circuits 3: One-Step Accordion Circuits
analyze_circuits_3.objective: Solve circuits with series components inside of parallel components or parallel sections in series.
analyze_circuits_3.content: Combinations of series and parallel resistor elements can be combined and taken apart to make a circuit.

electric_potential_diagrams_2.title: Electric Potential Diagrams 2
electric_potential_diagrams_2.objective: Given an electric potential diagram of a circuit, draw a circuit that could potentially be the correct circuit.
electric_potential_diagrams_2.content: The elements within a circuit can be determined from an electric potential diagram of that circuit.

algebraic_circuits_2.title: Algebraic Circuits 2
algebraic_circuits_2.subtitle: Solving Series and Parallel Circuits Algebraically
algebraic_circuits_2.objective: Algebraically determine voltage, current, resistance, and power of a circuit with only series and parallel elements; derive the formula for total resistance in a parallel circuit.

analyze_circuits_4.title: Analyze Circuits 4
analyze_circuits_4.subtitle: Demonstrating Kirchoff's Laws
analyze_circuits_4.objective: For circuits with multiple layers of series and parallel elements within each other, determine the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element and draw a diagram illustrating the electric potential of the circuit, and describe how the circuit diagram drawn illustrates Kirchoff's Laws.

dc_circuit_dimensional_analysis.title: DC Circuit Dimensional Analysis
dc_circuit_dimensional_analysis.objective: Determine and explain the units of all DC circuit quantities; prove various formulas are dimensionally correct.

algebraic_circuits_3.title: Algebraic Circuits 3
algebraic_circuits_3.subtitle: Solving Accordion Circuits Algebraically and Dimensional Analysis with Circuits
algebraic_circuits_3.objective: Algebraically solve circuits with series and parallel elements inside each other; demonstrate that the answers are dimensionally correct.

mathematically_rigorous_circuit_model.title: Mathematically Rigorous Circuit Model
mathematically_rigorous_circuit_model.objective: Define and use mathematically rigorous definitions of potential difference, current, resistance, and power; use Kirchoff's Laws to demonstrate basic circuit rules.

resistor_only_design.title: DC Circuit Design: Resistors Only
resistor_only_design.objective: Given a particular design goal, combine a set of resistors to accomplish this goal.

thermodynamics.title: Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.notes: These units need to be done together to be understood...for example, pods on definitions of temperature and pressure I wasn't sure where to include

kinetic_theory_of_matter_conceptual.title: Kinetic Theory of Matter Conceptual
notes: Many of these quizzes and examples need to be combined!
Does not include conduction, convection, and radiation, which must be added!

moving_molecules_1.title: Moving Molecules 1
moving_molecules_1.objective: Recognize where molecules move faster between different options.
moving_molecules_1.content: When an object is warmer, the molecules that make up that object move faster.

states_of_matter_1.title: States of Matter 1
states_of_matter_1.objective: Recognize how molecules move differently within different states of matter.
states_of_matter_1.content: All matter is made of moving molecules; molecules only vibrate in solids; molecules slip and slide in liquids; molecules move freely in a gas.

conduction_convection_radiation_1.title: Conduction, Convection, and Radiation 1
conduction_convection_radiation_1.objective: Recognize simple examples of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation
conduction_convection_radiation_1.content: Heat transfers by conduction when two objects touch; heat transfers by convection with fluids move; heat transfers by radiation through electromagnetic waves.

air_composition.title: Air Composition
air_composition.objective: Define what chemicals compose the air
air_composition.content: The air is composed of nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, water vapor, and argon

moving_molecules_2.title: Moving Molecules 2
moving_molecules_2.subtitle: Applications
moving_molecules_2.objective: Recognize and describe applications of molecules moving faster and slower
moving_molecules_2.content: Molecules move faster in objects with higher temperature and slower in objects with lower temperature; this fact produces observable results in the macroscopic world.
examples: Food coloring spreads faster in hot water
Smells spread faster in hot air.
Apply to thermal expansion
Apply to basic gas laws
trash smells worse in the summer than the winter

states_of_matter_2.title: States of Matter 2
states_of_matter_2.objective: Describe and draw diagrams showing how molecules move within each state of matter; and use the terms microscopic and macroscopic
states_of_matter_2.content: The macroscopic behavior of solids, liquids, and gasses can be correlated to the microscopic behavior of their atoms.

define_temperature.title: Define Temperature
define_temperature.objective: Define temperature as the average kinetic energy of molecules; define the kinetic theory of matter
define_temperature.content: Temperature is defined as the average kinetic energy of the molecules an an object (and/or a quantity that is equal when two objects are in thermal equilibrium); the kinetic theory of matter states that all matter is composed of moving molcules

conduction_convection_radiation_2.title: Conduction, Convection, and Radiation 2
conduction_convection_radiation_2.objective: Recognize simple examples of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation (but harder)
conduction_convection_radiation_2.content: Heat transfers by conduction when two objects touch; heat transfers by convection with fluids move; heat transfers by radiation through electromagnetic waves.

thermal_expansion.title: Thermal Expansion
thermal_expansion.objective: Describe, on both a microscopic and macroscopic level, why and how thermal expansion and contraction occur in solids, liquids, and gasses.
thermal_expansion.content: When temperature increases, molecules move faster and solids and liquids expand; when temperature decreases, molecuels move slower and solids and liquids contract.

air_pressure.title: Air Pressure
air_pressure.objective: Define air pressure, give examples of how air pressure applies, explain why humans do not feel air pressure, define atmospheric pressure.
air_pressure.content: Humans and all other objects are constantly bombarded by air molecules surrounding them, but do not feel it becuas it strikes every side of them equally.

entropy_1.title: Entropy 1
entropy_1.objective: Define entropy, give examples of high and low entropy, and state the second law of thermodynamics.
entropy_1.content: Entropy is the degree of randomness in a system; the second law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe is always increasing.

entropy_2.title: Entropy 2
entropy_2.objective: Draw how energy changes qualitative as an object moves (learned in another unit), relate these results to the second law of thermodynamics
entropy_2.content: If a physicist traces the conservation of energy in a process, it frequently ends with thermal energy; thermal energy is the random, not directed, motion of molecules; thermal energy represents the most random motion of energy
examples: kinetic energy turns to thermal energy when an object strikes the ground
kinetic energy turns to thermal energy when an object that was moving stops due to friction

changes_of_state.title: Changes of state
changes_of_state.objective: Explain what occurs on a molecular level during a change of state; explain why temperature does not change during a change of state
changes_of_state.content: When an object changes state, loose bonds between molecules either form or break; the molecules do not speed up or slow down.

conduction_thermal_equilibrium.title: Conduction and Thermal Equilibrium
conduction_thermal_equilibrium.objective: Relate heat transfer by conduction to the rules of heat transfer, kinetic theory, and the mechanics of collisions
conduction_thermal_equilibrium.content: Heat energy transfers from a warmer object to a cooler one until they have the same temperature; during heat conduction energy kinetic transfers through collisions until temperatures are equal.

evaporation.title: Evaporation
evaporation.objective: Contrast evaporation and boiling; explain how water cools due to evaporation; explain evaporation in open and closed containers.
evaporation.content: Evaporation cools water because faster moving water molecules leave the water due to evaporation; liquids are frequently cooler than their environments and do not reach thermal equilibrium; liquids in sealed containers can reach thermal equilibrium.

advanced_convection_and_radiation.title: Advanced Convection and Radiation
advanced_convection_and_radiation.objective: Relate heat radiation to our knowledge of electromagnetic waves
advanced_convection_and_radiation.content: All electromagnetic waves, but particularly infrared waves, transfer heat from one object to another.

entropy_3.title: Entropy 3
entropy_3.objective: Compare random and non-random motion of molecules; (describe entropy change in common examples of energy transfer) -> already in entropy 2
entropy_3.content: When an object moves its molecules move, but not randomly; but the random motion represents the heat energy.

brownian_motion.title: Brownian Motion
brownian_motion.objective: Describe how molecules appear to be moving by not traveling in a random walk model.
brownian_motion.content: Brownian motion is a more precise, mathematical way of analyzing molecules random motion.

entropy_probability.title: Entropy and Probability
entropy_probability.objective: Relate common processes to probability theory
entropy_probability.content: Principles of entropy follow when a physicist assumes that molecules move according to laws of probability.
examples: spreading perfume
jam mixed in pudding
entropy_probability.enrichment: Students should read/see the play 'Arcadia' by Tom Stoppard as a part of this lesson.

heat_formula_1.title: Heat Formula 1
heat_formula_1.objective: Determine the heat energy necessary to cause a temperature change.
heat_formula_1.content: The heat energy necessary to cause a change in temperature is equal to the mass of the object time sits specific heat times the change in temperature.

thermal_contact_1.title: Thermal Contact 1
thermal_contact_1.objective: Recognize (multiple choice) how heat will move when two objects are in thermal contact; determine when such a process ends.
thermal_contact_1.content: Heat energy moves from an object with higher temperature to an object with lower temperature until the two objects have the same temperature.

temperature_scales.title: Temperature Scales
temperature_scales.objective: Define the three (or four) temperature scales; give guidelines on temperature scale, know the difference between scales and units
temperature_scales.content: There are three different scales to measure temperature: Fahrenheit, Celsius, and Kelvin; these are called 'scales' rather than units because they have different zero-points
examples: Where does water boil on each scale?
What would a hot day be on each scale?
What would a cold day be on each scale?
Why do we say 'degrees Celsius' and 'degrees Fahrenheit' but never 'degrees Kelvin', just 'Kelvin'

temperature_conversions.title: Temperature Conversions
temperature_conversions.objective: Use formulas to convert temperatures between the three temperature scales.
temperature_conversions.content: Converting between different temperature scales involves both multiplying by a conversion factor and translating to a different zero point.

heat_formula_2.title: Heat Formula 2
heat_formula_2.objective: Solve the heat formula for mass or specific heat; determine what a material is based on specific heat.
heat_formula_2.content: The formula for heat energy can be solved for other quantities as well.

heat_graphs.title: Heat Graphs
heat_graphs.objective: Draw qualitative graphs of temperature as heat is added; describe and explain what happens when state changes in these graphs; identify the state of matter of an object base on temperature
heat_graphs.example: Can you ever have water with a temperature of -10 degrees celsius
heat_graphs.content: A heat graph shows how an object's temperature changes heat energy is added or removed; as an object changes state, heat energy is added or removed but the temperature of the object does not change

thermal_contact_2.title: Thermal Contact 2
thermal_contact_2.objective: Determine how heat will move when two objects are in thermal contact; determine when such a process ends.
thermal_contact_2.content: Heat energy moves from an object with higher temperature to an object with lower temperature until the two objects have the same temperature.

heat_formula_3.title: Heat Formula 3
heat_formula_3.objective: Solve heat formula problems asking for final or initial temperature.
heat_formula_3.content: Given the amount of heat added to an object, its mass, and its specific heat, a physicist can determine the intital or final temperature of the object.

heat_formula_4.title: Heat Formula 4: Multi-Step Problems
heat_formula_4.objective: Determine the amount of heat necessary to both head an object and change the state of matter of that object.
heat_formula_4.content: By combining the formula to heat needed to change temperature with the formula for heat needed to change state, a physicist can analyze the amount of heat energy necessary to progress through a multi-step process on a heat graph.

newtons_law_of_cooling.title: Newton's Law of Cooling
newtons_law_of_cooling.objective: Model the temperature of a cooling object as an exponential decay and connect this to the zeroeth law of thermodynamics.
newtons_law_of_cooling.content: An object that is placed in a cooler environment loses heat energy due to an exponential decay.

heat_formula_5.title: Heat Formula 5
heat_formula_5.subtitle: Multi-Step Solving for Temperature
heat_formula_5.objective: Solve a problem using the heat formula in which an object changes state of matter and you must determine final or initial temperature.
heat_formula_5.content: Through a more difficult mathematical process, physicists can determine the final or initial temperature of an object that has been through a multi-step process including changing temperature and changing state of matter.

heat_formula_mixture.title: Heat Formula 6
heat_formula_mixture.subtitle: Mixtures
heat_formula_mixture.objective: Determine the final temperature of a mixture; determine the heat capacity of an unknown substance by placing it in water.
heat_formula_mixture.content: When two items are mixed in a closed system, the heat energy added to one item is equal to the heat energy subtracted from the other; physicists can use this to create a new formula and find the final temperature of the mixture or other useful information.

determine_specific_heat.title: Heat Formula 7
determine_specific_heat.subtitle: Determine Specific Heat
determine_specific_heat.objective: Determine the specific heat of some metal using a calorimeter and water.
determine_specific_heat.content: Physicists can use a mixture of a substance and water in order to find the specific heat of the metal.

quantitative_gas_laws_thermal_expansion.title: Quantitative Gas Laws and Thermal Expansion
quantitative_gas_laws_thermal_expansion.notes: I need more on proving the ideal gas law and connecting it to the combined gas law.

thermal_expansion_formulas.title: Thermal Expansion Formulas
thermal_expansion_formulas.objective: Use the formulas for thermal expansion of a solid or liquid.

gas_laws_1.title: Gas Laws 1
gas_laws_1.objective: Use gas laws built only on proportionality.
gas_laws_1.limits: Very straightforward mathematical problems; no solving for a denominator

gas_laws_2.title: Gas Laws 2
gas_laws_2.objective: Use gas laws built only on proportionality
gas_laws_2.limits: Includes more inconvenient numbers and mathematical situations, such as solving for the denominator

combined_gas_law.title: Combined Gas Law
combined_gas_law.objective: Defend and solve the combined gas law; differentiate between the combined gas law and the ideal gas law; explain why gas laws are ueful and necessary

thermal_expansion_advanced.title: Thermal Expansion Advanced
thermal_expansion_advanced.objective: Solve complex real world thermal expansion problems, such as the thermal expansion of the oceans.

prove_ideal_gas_law.title: Prove the Ideal Gas Law
prove_ideal_gas_law.objective: Through both mathematical and conceptual arguments, prove the ideal gas law from the combined gas law.

heat_processes.title: Heat Processes
heat_processes.idea: This unit will deal with heat processes on P-V graphs.

parts_of_atom.title: Parts of an Atom
parts_of_atom.objective: Identify the parts of an atom, with a particular focus on the nucleus; identify that most of the mass but very little space is contained in the nucleus of an atom.
parts_of_atom.content: An atom is composed of neutrons and protons in a nucleus and electrons surrounding the nucleus; the nucleus comprises only a tiny portion of the space in an atom but almost all of the mass of an atom; nuclear physics deals with changes to the nucleus of an atom.

counting_parts_nucleus.title: Counting Parts of a Nucleus
counting_parts_nucleus.objective: Count the protons and neutrons in a nucleus; represent a nucleus in nuclide notation
counting_parts_nucleus.content: The atomic number of a nucleus gives the number of protons and the charge; the mass number gives the total number of protons and neutrons; nuclide notation represents a nucleus by its atoic symbol, charge, and mass.

atomic_mass_vs_mass_number.title: Atomic Mass vs. Mass Number
