atomic_mass_vs_mass_number.objective: Differentiate between atomic mass and mass number; explain when each is useful
atomic_mass_vs_mass_number.content: The mass number is the mass of an individual nucleus and the atomic mass is the average mass of all nuclei of that element.

alpha_beta_decay.title: Alpha and Beta Decay
alpha_beta_decay.objective: Draw reactions involving alpha or beta decay of an isotope.
alpha_beta_decay.content: In alpha decay, a nucleus gives off a Helium-4 nucleus; in beta decay a nucleus gives off an electron.

complete_nuclear_reaction.title: Complete a Nuclear Reaction
complete_nuclear_reaction.objective: Complete a nuclear reaction formula that has missing information; identify the reaction as fission, fusion, or decay.
complete_nuclear_reaction.content: A nuclear reaction is balanced by following the conservations of charge and mass; in a fission reaction a large nucleus breaks into many parts; in a fusion reaction multiple small nuclei combine to make a large nucleus

identify_crucial_particles.title: Identify Crucial Particles
identify_crucial_particles.objective: Identify the particles most crucial to understanding nuclear reactions.
identify_crucial_particles.content: The most important particles in nuclear reactions include alpha and beta particles, positrons, neutrinos, and different isotopes of hydrogen.

simple_half_life.title: Simple Half Life
simple_half_life.content: The half life of an nucleus is the time in which half of the mass of that isotope will have decayed.
simple_half_life.limits: Problems in this pod do not require the half-life to be represented as a function.
simple_half_life.example: If an isotope has a half-life of 3 years and you have 32 grams of the isotope, how much mass will you have after 9 years?

written_reactions_1.title: Written Reactions 1
written_reactions_1.objective: For a written description of a nuclear reaction, write the reaction in a proper formula.
written_reactions_1.content: A physicist can translate between nuclear reactions written in words and formulas of those reactions
written_reactions_1.example: uranium-238 undergoes alpha decay, write the reaction; a hydrogen atom and an alpha particle fuse, write the reaction

written_reactions_2.title: Written Reactions 2
written_reactions_2.objective: For a written description of a nuclear reaction, write the reaction in a proper formula; determine energy released by a nuclear reaction.
written_reactions_2.content: A physicist can translate between nuclear reactions written in words and formulas of those reactions
written_reactions_2.notes: This crucial topic should be broken into two sections

half_life_formulas.title: Half-Life Formulas
half_life_formulas.objective: Represent half-life through an exponential decay function; use these formulas properly
half_life_formulas.content: The half-life can be represented mathematically through an exponential decay function.

calculate_atomic_mass.title: Calculate Atomic Mass
calculate_atomic_mass.objective: Calculate the atomic mass of an element from a weighted average of isotopes and explain the purpose of this calculation.
calculate_atomic_mass.content: Atomic mass is calculated through a weighted average of all isotopes of an element.

decay_chain.title: Decay Chain
decay_chain.objective: Use a table of isotopes to draft a decay chain for a particular isotope.
decay_chain.content: A table of isotopes shows the decay patterns of each isotope; a physicist can use this information to show the process by which a nucleus decays until it becomes a stable nucleus.

nuclear_reactions_sun.title: Nuclear Reactions in the Sun
nuclear_reactions_sun.objective: Write and analyze the nuclear reactions occurring inside the sun; explain how they produce energy.
nuclear_reactions_sun.content: Nuclear fusion reactions in the sun release enormous amounts of energy.

remnants_isotope.title: Remnants of an Isotope
remnants_isotope.objective: Based upon the decay chain and the half-life of a particular isotope, identify at particular times what different products you will have and what radiation they will give off; identify what percentages of each element you will have at different times.
remnants_isotope.content: By combining information about a decay chain with the half life of each step, a physicist can determine what amounts of different elements will be present after a certain time spend decaying.
remnants_isotope.notes: Good lead-in to a computation problem; should include some discussion of Technetium

nuclear_reaction_basic_concepts.title: Nuclear Reaction Basic Concepts
nuclear_reaction_basic_concepts.objective: Identify parts of an atom; know that nuclear reactions occur only in the nucleus of the atom; define terms 'radioactive' and 'radioactivity

fission_fusion_decay.title: Fission, Fusion, and Decay
fission_fusion_decay.objective: Differentiate between three types of nuclear reactions: fission, fusion, and decay

nuclear_vs_chemical_reactions.title: Nuclear vs. Chemical Reactions
nuclear_vs_chemical_reactions.objective: Differentiate between nuclear and chemical reactions; identify whether a formula depicts a nuclear reaction or a chemical reaction.

nuclear_reaction_danger.title: Nuclear Reaction Danger
nuclear_reaction_danger.objective: Assess the danger of different types of nuclear reactions
nuclear_reaction_danger.notes: Requires previous knowledge of the electromagnetic spectrum.

nuclear_reactions_stars.title: Nuclear Reaction in the Stars
nuclear_reactions_stars.objective: Explain the processes of stars by using the concept of nuclear reaction.

artificially_created_elements_1.title: Artificially Created Elements 1
artificially_created_elements_1.objective: Explain how new elements can be artificially created; draw reactions that go with those examples.

artificially_created_elements_2.title: Artificially Created Elements 2
artificially_created_elements_2.objective: Explain more complex examples of how new elements can be artificially created; draw reactions that go with those examples.

isotopes_uranium.title: Isotopes of Uranium
isotopes_uranium.objective: Explain the importance of different isotopes of uranium for the creation of a nuclear reactor or a nuclear bomb; examine how different isotopes are isolated.

periodic_table_cosmology.title: Periodic Table Cosmology
periodic_table_cosmology.objective: Explain, using descriptions of reactions, how heavier elements within the universe can be created.

energy_levels.title: Energy Levels
energy_levels.objective: Determine the difference between different energy levels of an atom.

photons_atoms.title: Photons and Atoms
photons_atoms.objective: Explain how and why photons of a precise energy can be emitted or absorbed by an atom, refer to electrons and energy levels in your answer

energy_levels_photons.title: Energy Levels and Photons
energy_levels_photons.objective: Given an atom of various energy levels, determine the wavelength, frequency, and color or type of wave that can be emitted by that atom.

ionizing_radiation.title: Ionizing Radiation
ionizing_radiation.objective: Differentiate between ionizing and non-ionizing radiation

cell_phone_controversy.title: Cell Phone Controversy
cell_phone_controversy.objective: Evaluate the danger of devices that emit electromagnetic waves such as cellphones; defend choices using knowledge of atomic structure and electromagnetic waves.

bands_spectrum.title: Bands in Spectrum
bands_spectrum.objective: Given a spectrum showing bands of particular wavelengths, recognize the bands by consulting a table of energy levels.

neon_lights.title: Neon Lights
neon_lights.objective: Use the chemical composition of a neon tube to determine what color a neon light will shine.

astrochemistry.title: Astrochemistry
astrochemistry.objective: Determine the chemical composition of an astronomical body using a spectrum of that body and a table of energy levels between atoms; defend choices.

basic_quantum_theory.title: Basic Quantum Theory
basic_quantum_theory.notes: A brief introduction to some concepts that would be covered in a college quantum mechanics course, but not including solutions to the Schrodinger equation.
